description: One week into wearing a white shirt and blue jeans every day for a year, I was out in the rain with a pink, tie-dyed sweatshirt on. I got soaked, and some of the dye from the sweatshirt sept through onto the shirt. At that point, I thought of the idea of starting each day with a new blank white shirt and making something new on that shirt by the end of the day.

The project is underway. I began my morning with a 40-minute walk to Michaels' to pick up fabric markers and a week's worth of blank white Gildan tees. I went over to the school to meet up with A and Z in the Parsons building as Z finished her final painting of the semester. I decided to put a drum major on this shirt to represent a beginning.

Nostalgia is a running theme throughout the number of shirts, beginning with this photo of me as a baby with my dog, Sparky. Being able to wear a piece of personal history on my chest felt empowering. Sparky passed away when I was ten. We used to sing a song that went "who farted? Wasn't me! Wasn't me! Must've beenâ€¦ Sparkyyyyy!!!" RIP Sparky.

The baby onesie shirt is the first of those following a theme of disruption or confusion. The looks I got that day felt so cool. Four different people asked if I was a father, which just felt funny as a 21-year-old. This is the beginning of a series of shirts where I really just wanted to introduce strange, new, and humorous ideas. That night I had fun running around, playing basketball, and feeling like a kid.

The first boarding pass shirt. This follows the idea of introducing strange, funny ideas that make people do a double-take. I met up with my dad in Chicago before connecting on a flight to Salt Lake City. Before boarding the plane, the flight attendant working the ticketing called out over the loudspeaker to have everyone look at my shirt. He got a good laugh out of it. On the plane, a woman who works for United asked to take my picture.
Grandfather clock. I spent about four hours in a car driving from Salt Lake City to Moab, Utah, so the passing of time was present on my mind.
Horse flies. I don't even know what I was thinking with this one. I just started with a horse and some circles and just kept adding things until I liked it.

Map of Arches National Park. I spent close to three hours drawing this shirt after spending the previous day learning about the park. The sleeve features a stamp that would be used to be placed in a National Park Passport. I love the detail in this shirt, especially as it is inherently tied to a specific place and time.
Gildan sticker. Continuing with the theme of humor, and only having about 10 minutes to make the shirt, I replicated the sticker found on the shirt.
First nine days review shirt. Features my first mistake, where I switched the order of the boarding pass and grandfather clock shirts. Getting a little bit meta too.

Secretary of State Jesse White. I got my license renewed this day and decided to put the sign above the DMV on my shirt. A DMV employee asked if I worked there, and if I was her boss. I had my little sister, Katy, take a photo of me in front of the DMV. She was there to get an official state ID.

Clown button-up shirt. I wanted to edit the shirt in any sort of way possible, and this ended up being one of the few days where my method was cutting and sewing. Throughout the entire project, I was certain that I would return to more cut-and-sew techniques but I felt that I was able to more easily express many of the thoughts and ideas I wanted to convey by designing graphically.

Horizontal button-up shirt. I did not like the clown button-up shirt. It felt far too simple, not introducing any sort of new ideas. One of the first "there's always tomorrow" shirts, where I tried to advance the concepts or ideas that I did not enjoy on the previous day.

I was introduced to the one-year performances of Tehching Hsieh and began to see the project as more of a performance, rather than a visual art or fashion project. I decided to feature the solitary confinement cage from Hsieh's first one-year performance on my shirt. His work centered around growing in his understanding of himself, which I aimed to address with this project.

Shoot your senators. No, seriously, use guns and fucking kill your senators. I was pissed off in the wake of the Uvalde school shooting. The back features the names of the children who died in the Uvalde shooting, which I wish I hadn't added because it makes it a bit grim but I suppose fitting.

My little pony with a graduation cap for K's high school graduation. K is a big fan of My Little Pony, and wrote a powerful piece connecting her love of MLP to her personal power for her college admission essays.

I thought a park scene would be sweet and cool, but when I got to the park it was basically a dump and construction site. I grew up going to Maple Park all the time so returning to it to see it undergoing renovations was a bit of a shock to me. I dove into that with this shirt and kicked and stained the shirt in the grass and dirt once I was done with my drawing.

Unnatural dye shirt. I also thought it was cool how the stitching remained white, so I flipped the shirt inside out and sewed the tag on the other side to reverse the wear of the shirt. At that point I was still just experimenting and trying to dip my toes into as many different modes of editing the shirts as possible, but I really like how this one turned out looking like it had been stained in a mechanic shop or with some sort of oil. At a later point my shirts would be stained in that way just through everyday wear.

I flew from Chicago back to New York and spent the duration of the flight drawing images from the plane safety card onto a shirt. Before the plane landed I went to the bathroom to switch into my new shirt.

Siamese twins shirt. I cut out felt and recreated a design I made with construction paper, taking inspiration from the paper cut-outs Monet made late in his life, and a paper cut-out design I had made on the night at Z's sister's place that inspired the project.

I spent about three hours out in the scorching sun at the East River Park rubbing clumps of grass into the shirt to dye the shirt green. My initial idea was to dye the shirt just by rolling around in the grass but quickly learned that that would not work. A helped me, and we went home with green hands and fingernails.

My first spray-paint shirt, at first just with an "X" on the front and back, but I didn't like that because it looked like a lame rip-off of Off-White. So I painted "LUNCH LUNCH LUNCH, DINNER DINNER DINNER, EAT EAT" on the shirt because I was probably hungry and pissed off that I was hungry and had to find some way to nourish my body by means of cooking or spending money.

The New York Rangers were in the playoffs and the city was so happy about it, so I made a shitty version of their logo to support. They lost that night and were knocked out of the playoffs a few days later. I think it was my fault.

Warhol-inspired banana block print. For a while, I had eaten a banana for breakfast every day and decided to use a peel as a stamp. Looking back, I wish I had thought harder about the range of possibilities of what could be used as a stamp.
My favorite show at the time was "The Dropout" starring Amanda Seyfried as Elizabeth Holmes. I thought it was funny to pretend Amanda Seyfried was actually Elizabeth Holmes.

One of my favorite shirts of the entire project, I sewed a paintbrush onto the center of my shirt and decided to paint the entire shirt while I was wearing it. At first the shirt was just going to have a paintbrush sewn to the center of it but it felt too plain to me so then I found some paint and went out to the park to paint it in public. This was one of the first shirts where I began to look at each day as a piece of conceptual fine art rather than just a shirt. Continues with the theme of performance.

For this shirt, I walked around the city asking strangers to sign my shirt, starting the day by tying a sharpie on a string to my shirt. This was hard because a lot of people said no and thought I was just some weirdo. It was perfect though because G's EP release party was that night, and I had tons of people to sign the shirt.

I recreated the 2x My Weight album cover, which my roommate G had just released, using spray paint, sticks, fossilized flowers, and a candle sewn to my shirt. G's project was incredibly inspiring to me going into the shirt project, as I would hear him every day working on the songs relentlessly. I was jealous of his motivation to create and needed that for myself. Now I had that for myself, and was able to honor him.
materials: spray paint, sticks, fossilized flowers, candle

description: ILY shirt. I cut apart my football jersey and used the pieces to form a heart in the middle of the shirt. I walked around the Guggenheim Museum in this shirt and felt like such an artist by wearing my own creation on my chest. At the museum, I learned about some cool performance art pieces, like 60 Minutes Silence and Dancing in Peckham.

Continuing with the concept of love and repurposing of clothing, I safety-pinned a "Somebody in New York loves me" shirt to the front of my white shirt. Where the previous day I had walked around telling everyone I loved them, this day was focused on more self-love.

For this shirt, I was inspired by the wheat-pasted posters of some women at a beach. I brought out my fabric markers, nails, and a hammer and nailed the shirt up to the scaffolding wood, and drew the women from the posters onto my shirt. This was also the day I met R and was the beginning of a whirlwind of a relationship. Fitting that my two previous shirts focused on love, and then that was introduced into my life the following day.

I liked the holes in my previous day's shirt, but I needed even more holes. So I decided to put the shirt over a wooden board I had found and nailed 168 nails into a shirt in a pattern that would conform with the body. My shoulders and back were so sore afterward from bending over and hammering all day. I saved that piece of wood with all the nails in it and it became a fun game where you could put a coin in the top and let the coin fall until it reached a resting point.

On certain days I would find myself wanting to make more "wearable" rather than "unwearable" shirts. Designs that were more practical and suitable for long-term wear, rather than a focus on a concept or a creation of something that no one had ever seen before. The powerlifter had become a powerful symbol in my life, especially because of a specific line on G's EP.

This one was simple because I was focused on spending my day buying and framing some collages I had made that would be in a gallery show the next day. And the Yankees logo is just so iconic, I felt like making a little fucked-up version of it would be cool.

This is a recreation of my Princess Diana weed bag collage for the opening of my first-ever gallery show at 420 E 9th Street. I had met Tito, the owner of the gallery, about a week earlier and he was happy to make some wall space for my work. Now, almost every time I'm walking down that street Tito will see me from across the street and yell "Jack!". I really enjoy having these cool little community relationships. It makes me feel like I belong.
Just some ampersands on the side of the shirt yeah I don't know what to say but it looks cool. I think it was inspired by some basketball shorts.

I figured out I could use an inkjet printer to print onto fabric, so I put a baby doll on my shirt because I'm pretty sure it was Father's Day too. The only issue here is that the ink will bleed if the fabric gets wet so this one is really unwearable.

Just added a bunch of strings to the shirt. Again really unwearable but presents new ideas. I spent the day playing basketball at the East River Park by myself, running back and forth across the court as the strings swung around with every movement.

I sewed a compass onto my shirt, which was perfect because I spent my night adventuring and writing graffiti with R. Certain shirts like this one became really spiritual in the way they represented or foreshadowed the actions I took that day. That night R and I wanted to write graffiti on the freight trains on the railroad tracks of Myrtle Ave, which I had heard about but had never actually seen freight trains when I had been there before. After climbing on top of a train and hopping a fence, we found ourselves in a lot full of tourist buses.

This day I really wanted to tattoo the drum major from day 2 onto the back of my calf, but at a certain point, I realized it would be nearly impossible to get the angle right so I ended up just using the shirt to rub that stencil off the back of my leg. I still need to get that drum major tattoo.

I had saved this idea for a few weeks, already having bought a pill sorter and figuring out that I would one day put it on a shirt. I chose to do it on this day because I was attending the Making It Collective group show. I knew I had to make one of the most unique and strange shirts I had made so far in order to impress the group of artists. This day ended up being incredibly important to me and to this project, as I would meet an incredible group of people who I admired and was able to talk to for support throughout the year.

This is another spiritual shirt, as it represented an opening up and letting the goodness of the world come to me. I spent another day adventuring and wound up stranded in upstate New York with R that night after hiking and painting graffiti at a park. We went skinny dipping in a lake and stayed out too late to catch any trains back to the city, so we had to hitchhike back to R's parent's house, who I met while being grimy, covered in cuts and mud from being barefoot out in the woods.

This day includes another unwearable inkjet print, with an added extra layer of un-wearability as I smeared ice cream all over it after coming across a live piece of performance art where the audience was encouraged to throw and rub ice cream on dancers.

This shirt was made for Pride, the best and most fun holiday in New York. I was really unsure of what to make because it was K and A's birthdays as well, but I felt like "bloom" was a good way to represent the day and pride as a whole. I had been beginning to question my gender identity more, and I really enjoyed having the flower to visually represent a penis and the pot to represent a vagina. I had begun to see the freedom of thinking of oneself as existing outside of one specific gender, at least personally and mentally.

I was listening to this song by Dean Blunt called "grandiosee" a lot and working on this graffiti project where I was writing out ten pages of a story on ten different walls around the city. The project as a whole felt very over the top and magnificent, while also having a certain dichotomy in the graffiti as a medium being very grungy and not so magnificent. This shirt also features some raspberries that I rubbed into the shirt.

This is probably the grimiest shirt of them all because I spent an entire 24 hours moving and cleaning out my entire apartment. I got drenched in sweat. But I still had time to find a sink faucet that someone had left outside, so I used that as a stencil and ended up making something that I really enjoyed. Sometimes a really beautiful shirt only takes about 5 minutes to make. Those are some of my favorites.

This features R's body printed onto a shirt. I think this one was her idea actually, so I covered her in paint and pressed the shirt against her body. I was only up for a few hours that day, being exhausted after spending the entire previous day and night moving boxes up and down stairs and into a U-Haul, so I was really happy that I was still able to make a shirt that day.

The bike stencil shirt is an early favorite of mine and an example of how inspiration and incredible visuals can really be found in the most mundane and everyday parts of life. I just went outside with a shirt and a can of spray paint and ended up using the old bike that had been abandoned outside of my apartment as a stencil.

This was my first day living in my new apartment after I spent another entire day moving. My favorite part of my new room was the fire escape outside of my window, which really let me feel free after feeling trapped in a tiny box at my old place. The bars of the fire escape that I used as a stencil kind of contrasted that feeling.

I was feeling really healthy at this point in my life because I would be eating my daily banana and eating so much Sweetgreen all the time. Little did I know that living in my new place I would have far less Sweetgreen access and begin eating a lot more fried chicken and pizza.
I just thought this would be funny. Cranes. Lol. Also spent the day drawing a new style of "meditation loops" I was developing all over my legs in green marker.

This shirt was made for the Fourth of July, and was another protest shirt in the wake of the repealing of Roe v. Wade, questioning the notion of what it means to be free in America. It kind of gives communism vibes though because M had a can of yellow spray paint was drunk and begging me for like 10 minutes to add something to my shirt. I regret giving in.

This day I just had some fun doing some block prints on my shirts with a scrap of lino. A lot of times I would find myself falling in love with residual parts of the process that could be beautiful in their own ways. I had also gotten into tattooing at this time, and R let me tattoo some freeform designs onto the bottom of her foot, which must have hurt like hell, but I was grateful that she let me practice. The designs faded after just a few weeks from being walked on.

I squirted some tattoo ink onto the shirt and added some lines to flow with the body forms. Nothing much here other than I was really wanting new tattoos and wanted to mess around with my tattoo gun. On this day, I tattooed a design originally made by my great uncle, Carl Moravec, onto my thigh. The "X" formed by the cross of the table legs represented strength for me, and mirrored the table given to me by my grandpa that I would use every day for creating my art.

This day I rolled some green ink on my foot and just stomped onto the middle of the shirt. This night I was also invited to the Shrek rave, which I did not end up attending but the shirt would have been perfect. During the last week of the project, this day came full circle as the creator of the Shrek rave reached out to me looking for some custom shirts.

This day I was tripping on mushrooms and going kind of crazy alone in my room. I was frustrated and tired of making shirts that I felt were ugly, so for this shirt, I just bunched up the shirt on the floor, stuck a stick of incense in it, and stared at it for 30 minutes as it burned down and dropped ashes onto the shirt. This was a spiritual moment for me, and an awakening to the fact that I could make the shirts as abstract as I wanted.

Another unwearable shirt, I found a mini tin mailbox on the side of the road and decided to glue it to the center of my shirt. I used some magnets on the inside of the shirt to reinforce the mailbox and make sure it wouldn't fall off. I also wrote a letter to my future self that I would read on the last day of the project, but I ended up reading it sooner and throwing the letter away because it was really depressing to read. I was not very happy at this point in my life.

This was the first day that I failed to make a shirt. I promised R I would go to the beach with her and her friends and had to wake up at 8 AM to leave, but I had just run out of blank shirts the day before. I ended up being at the beach all the way until sundown, and by the time I got home, there were no places open for me to buy a blank shirt. The next day I drilled a hole in a shell that I had found at the beach and sewed it on to the center of the shirt.

I had felt an imbalance between the left and right sides of my body. Sometimes the left half of my body would feel more natural and in tune with the world, and other times it would be the right side. I made this shirt with arrows pointing in both directions to disperse and diffuse the energy across both sides of my body. I think it worked.

After a few weeks of living in my new apartment, we still had not purchased hooks to hang up a new shower curtain and were using a mattress bag as a shower curtain. The mattress bag would fill up with water and you would have to squeeze it to push the water out. So after getting new shower hooks, I decided to use them as stencils on this shirt.

I was tripping on mushrooms again on this day and had just gone to Michaels to buy some new shirts. The project as a whole felt strange to me, so I sat in Washington Square Park and wrote the word "GREED" on my shirt while holding another shirt in my hand. At one point I bought and started smoking a joint, and some guy came up to me and kept begging me to buy him weed or give him my joint.

For this shirt, me and my roommates G and A along with our friend B were headed up to New Paltz for a party that night, and I wanted to make something relatively impressive. So I drew a large face with all sorts of colors and did it in a really rushed-out fashion. G dubbed it "the schizophrenia shirt". That night ended up being one of the most fun nights in my recent memory.

After a long night the previous day, I think I just wanted to do something relatively simple for this shirt, but still in pursuit of my own personal style. I had begun to be entranced by these one-line drawings I was making, calling them "meditation loops" because you could place your finger at any point on the line and continue to follow the line infinitely in an almost trance-like way. I was experimenting with this style, and trying to draw distinct forms and figures with the limitation of a single, smooth line. This one is an old-timey, throne-like chair.

Continuing with the one-line drawing style, this shirt features an ethereal, angel-like figure. Sometimes I would aim for simplicity and fewer gestures with these one-line-drawings, but more complex ones like these are cool to me because of the smoothness and flow of all the forms that developed throughout the drawing.

This shirt works almost in contrast to the one-lined chair from two days earlier, featuring one of the most simply constructed chairs you could think of. I really liked the color combination of pink and orange. I was thinking of adding the words "sit with me" under the chair as I was needing to have a conversation with someone important in my life on that day but I didn't want to make things too explicit or obvious so I stuck with just the chair.

Another one-line drawing, but this one takes up the whole shirt and is less focused. I was trying to almost collage together facial structures with this line, abstracting things as much as I could. I think the color of the line has a lot of influence on the meaning of each of the one-line pieces, and this one, being a black line, makes it the coldest, most constructed, or rigid despite the line still flowing in a smooth nature.

Ok so for this shirt I wanted to be more patient and calm down a bit on some things I was trying to rush. And I know, it seems like I purposefully misspelled patience to be funny or something but I literally was too impatient to look up how to properly spell it and then realized my mistake after already making the shirt. It really sounds like the word should be spelled "paitence" but I guess not. I wish I hadn't added that arrow and made this shirt so obvious.

I had begun to feel too restricted by the medium of the shirt and also didn't really like all of the designs I was making and had to wear every day, so I tried to break beyond the medium of the shirt while still working with its limitations. This turned me to create the "shainting", where I glued the shirt of the day onto a canvas, or in this case, a huge piece of wood, and made a huge painting over top of the canvas with the shirt disguised within it.

This is the second "shainting", but the one I didn't like as much because it just felt like I ripped off Basquiat. I had a huge appreciation for the freedom and simplicity of his work and wanted to recreate something in his style to show my daily trips to the deli, where I would be getting a sandwich or a Yerba Mate or a coffee or snacks or whatever. That daily repetitive process made me feel like a cog in a system almost and had me wanting to break free.

This shirt was more of a reflection on myself, as I found myself glued to my phone day after day and also with a dreadful feeling of boredom day after day. I was stressed out and anxious as hell for no real reason, so I thought that maybe I should just go read a book or something. I don't really remember what book I was reading (or trying to read) at this point, but it was probably "The Art Spirit" by Robert Henri.

This shirt is dedicated to the band Sweet Trip, which I had been listening to a ton when I made this shirt. My favorite Sweet Trip songs, in no particular order, are: Sept, Milk, Your World is Eternally Complete, Darkness, Dsco, Things to Ponder While Falling, Chocolate Matter, International, and Air Supply.

I made this "Matban" shirt because I thought it would be funny to draw some really messed up and ugly-looking Batmans, but I was really influenced by watching a bunch of Batman movies in the previous days. The Robert Pattinson one was really good but I had never watched any of the Dark Knight trilogy before that week and really all those movies are great. I remember on this day I went to S's bake sale in Prospect Park and had a really delicious lemon zest raspberry tarte cake that she had made.

Not really sure what I was going for with this shirt, other than creating some sort of metallic or chrome-looking figure of a face. I was really enjoying amorphic and chrome-looking things in the general aesthetics I observed at the time, which influenced this shirt.

A few weeks earlier, I think my roommate A had given me one of those eggs that you would put the small rubber thing inside in some water and watch it grow, so I just had this dinosaur sitting in a bowl of water on my desk for a few weeks and wanted to finally do something with it. Cutting blocks to print takes a lot of time and energy, but realizing that almost anything can be a block to print with is a lot of fun.
I had been getting so many spam emails, which definitely inspired this scammer shirt. I probably saw something on the internet too about scamming which led me to make this shirt.

I call this shirt the star-eyed monster shirt, which I made because stars are my absolute favorite motif. The star is a good-luck charm for me. For the longest, my go-to motif was the smiley face, but eventually, I grew out of that. And probably, eventually, I will grow out of the star too. But throughout the year I had a few cheat garments that I allowed myself to wear instead of my white shirt, largely depending on the temperature. On hot days, I had my star tank, which was passed on to me by my dad and just features a single star in the middle.

This shirt was one of my favorites for a while after I had made it, with the borders and stitching of the shirt spray-painted with pink and orange paint. This one feels kinda like some sort of designer piece to me, with its simplicity yet edginess with the spray paint.

As I introduced in the shirt from day 65, the pink and orange color combo really attracted me. I wanted to continue with my one-line style and drew a one-line alphabet for this shirt. The pitfall of this one is actually that pink and orange combo, which makes it kinda look like the shirt was made by Popeyes.

Oftentimes I would recreate or reiterate some of my favorite shirts, and this is one of those shirts. This is a recreation of the outline shirt which I really enjoyed and felt that I could really wear with anything. For this, I simply replaced the orange from two days earlier with blue. I spray-painted this in my room, which was terrible for me and might lead to some lung cancer or some sort of disease in twenty years, but I was being young and reckless.

I found this cool gold frame on the street and wanted to continue with my "shainting" style or medium or whatever you would call it, so I affixed the shirt onto the frame and painted a one-line shirt onto the shirt itself. Even when I'm being "serious" as an artist (i.e. making a painting) I still like to bring a bit of humor or irony into it. I love this piece and take it very seriously.

A lot of times I would drive myself crazy over this girl R. I was listening to the song "u" by Kendrick Lamar that day and I was waiting the entire day for R to get to my place. I think I got the word that she wouldn't be coming, or maybe she was, but either way, the "u" on the shirt was for R. She had just reiterated to me that the hug we shared on day 45 was the happiest moment of her life, and I was obsessed with her, but a lot of times I would find myself in an indescribable sadness thinking about her, hence "loving u is complicated".

Another frame I found on the street and wanted to make a "shainting" out of, but this one was smaller so I had to do something a little different. I really liked the one-line shirt drawing I had made, which I turned into a logo for myself, and continued with this motif for much of the week. This night was S's birthday, and we went over to a friend's rooftop to celebrate, where I climbed a water tower on the roof and got to see her for the first time since we had separated.

Another frame, another shainting. Except this one ended up breaking one day while I was walking around the corner of my apartment too quickly and I knocked it off the wall, so it's actually one of the wearable shaintings because the frame no longer exists with it. This features three one-line shirts layered over top of one another, but without that context one might be able to think it looks like a whole bunch of different things.

I spent this day out walking around in the heat, searching for more frames to make shaintings with. I didn't end up getting lucky and finding more boxes of frames on the street, so I ended up walking to a frame shop and buying two of the cheapest frames I could find. I didn't like the overflow of the shirt on this one, so I ended up cutting the square of the frame out from the center of the shirt, effectively creating two shirts out of one that day.

The final shainting I would create throughout the project, I felt at this point I had let the idea run its course and didn't want to have to go out and buy any more frames, but I just made this one-line shirt more blocky and in a slightly different style than the other one-line figures I had been painting.

This shirt, for all of its simplicity, was incredibly important to me. I simply wrote "I Can Do Anything" on the back of my shirt, just to empower myself. This day, I went with R to the city to attend a Kundalini yoga class with her. I was one of the only guys in there, and probably the only person who was trying it for the first time. It was so incredibly difficult, but I pushed myself and worked really hard, and felt really moved both physically and mentally by the end of the class.

This shirt was made on a Monday, on which day I had a ritual of listening to my favorite song even more than usual. The song is "Avant Gardener" by Courtney Barnett, and the shirt features the opening lines of that song. This was the first song I learned about by Courtney, but I had recently started listening to the rest of her music a lot more and was absolutely in love with it.

This shirt features the iconic image of Nathan Fielder from his show "The Rehearsal", wearing his laptop body holster. I remember getting more likes and responses on this shirt than I had ever gotten before, which was an initial motivation to begin making more references to popular media and relatable shirts that were less personal to me but more accessible to a wider audience.

This shirt simply features the word "innate" on the back of the shirt. Around this time I had just been wanting to wear a blank white shirt so the small iterations would be coming on the backs. The word innate was a reference to my own artistic ability, or just ability to create, but done so in a semi-ironic way as it is placed on the back. It almost serves as a reminder to myself that my abilities, or just who I am, is innate, something I was born with.

I had recently been given the book "The Hidden Messages in Water" by my roommate, G, and in that book there is an experiment referenced where the words "love and gratitude" were written on a clear glass of water and contrasted with another cup that said something like "evil and hate". According to the experiment, when frozen, the water cup with "love and gratitude" formed the most beautiful and intricate crystals while the other cup formed jagged and scary-looking crystal structures. This shirt was a way of performing that experiment on myself and imbuing myself with the power of those words.

I don't really remember where or how this idea came to me but I really liked this shirt. I remember my uncle showing me how to draw a boy's face with the word "boy" so I think that had something to do with this. Anyways, it was a "GOOD" day.

This is the first of a few I began where I would paint rectangular designs onto the back of shirts with spray paint and masking tape to create the designs. This night I was going out to one of R's shows in the city and I think that city nights sort of theme inspired this one. I remember staying out with her late after the show. We sat on the stoop outside of Heaven Can Wait long after everyone else had left the show and had a good time just being together.

I loved the design I had made the previous day so I decided to work in the same sort of style, using spray paint and stencils in a rectangle on the back of the shirt. This was a design where I wanted to focus more on my technical skills of accurately painting and shading in a cool way, rather than doing any sort of experiment or having any sort of deeper meaning. I don't think the designs always have to mean something. Sometimes they can just look cool or be made well.

This was one of my favorite designs I had ever made in the early days and led me to start creating a few extra pieces a day to sell on the side. This Picasso-inspired face just felt really well-made in my opinion and was relatively easy to make. I felt an infinite range of possibilities for what could be created within that rectangle and felt like I could more easily make things that people really liked, thought was cool, and wanted to wear.

Again, just an abstract kind of design that somehow came to me. I think I called this one 4D chess and was inspired by the story of Atlas holding up the weight of the world. I spent a solid hour meticulously cutting this stencil from newsprint paper, which is kind of crazy to me now because I spent all that effort creating a complicated stencil that I wouldn't be able to reuse.

I think I saw a picture of a girl sitting cross-legged by some photographer on Instagram, and I just thought it was a cool image so that's what I made with this shirt. I didn't feel as if I executed this one the way I really wanted to, but at the same time there is always the next day.

I spent this morning going to the spray paint store near me to pick up some new colors, as I was recently beginning to work almost exclusively with spray paint, even though it wasn't so good for the shirt fabric and certainly not good for my lungs. For this shirt I envisioned the up-close angle of a thumb flicking a lighter, and kind of just went for it drawing out the design and cutting the stencil.

This shirt is inspired by the painting of the girl with the pearl earring, done in a simplified and abstract way. I wanted to create something that felt sexy yet amorphic and natural. I really enjoy this design quite a lot.

I liked and was inspired by artists who would include references to pop culture or brands in their work, and created this Clorox bottle design inspired by that. I would be searching for inspiration wherever I could find it, and for this shirt I found it sitting on my desk after cleaning up the spray paint particles that dusted all the surfaces of my bedroom.

This shirt was special to me, being the hundredth day of the project. I had thought of this idea a while back, wanting to sew 100 pennies to the shirt for day 100. R liked my idea and bought me a miniature hole puncher to punch holes in pennies. I spent the entire day punching holes and sewing the pennies onto the shirt and had crazy carpal tunnel in my hand by the end of the day. The force it took to punch each hole was insane, and at a certain point, it became incredibly difficult to sew new pennies onto the shirt just because of the weight of the others moving the shirt all over the place, and with my poor sewing skills pennies began falling off. So I didn't finish this shirt, which I had been looking forward to for so long.

This Pikachu shirt dives into my greatest childhood obsession, PokÃ©mon. I knew I had wanted to make a PokÃ©mon shirt earlier, but was kind of held back by people in my immediate circle not thinking it was cool or whatever.

Following the theme of the previous day, and needing to make a shirt really quickly because I had a flight to catch, I made this Magikarp shirt. I was going to see my sisters later that day and I knew that they would like it, and I was going to my childhood home so that element of nostalgia had an influence on the making of this one.

The previous day, I had spent my entire flight drawing abstract faces with Posca markers in my sketchbook. Sketching is really important in the development of a personal style. This day I was riding with my mom and sister to go thrifting in Andersonville and made this shirt on the car ride over. I ended up picking up a jacket that I really liked and spent hours drawing a face with Posca markers on it. This was the first day I switched from drawing with Tulip markers to Posca markers, which is the medium I would work with for a while until I picked up airbrushing.

Another Posca marker abstract face. Often times when I would travel or go home I would stick to simpler and less time-intensive designs, which oftentimes would also work in my favor as I was able to break whatever style I was on and then get into a new style that I would really enjoy. At the time, the feeling of travel would be difficult and feel like a setback, but that difficulty would lead to growth.

On my final day in Chicago, I made another simple face sort of figure. Something I found really cool about the Posca markers was the ability they gave me to blend colors in a way that the Tulip markers didn't really allow me to do.

I was back in New York, and inspired by the city, I made a Thank You stencil that features the font found on bags you would get from the bodega. After this, I ended up making another "You're Welcome" stencil that I did not end up featuring on any of my daily tees because I wanted to sell that design on the side, and I had a rule that all of the daily shirts must be one of one and that I would not copy any of them to sell then, even though I needed money and people wanted some of the designs I had already made.

On this day, R's parents were out of town so I ended up going up to Armonk with her to spend the day in the quiet of being outside of the city. At this point in our relationship, subtle problems had started to arise, and I think the idea of "draw" kind of referenced a bit of a stalemate between the two of us. Also, this one is meant to be funny in a way, as I "draw" referenced what I was doing every day and how I made the shirt.

This morning, R and I arrived back from Armonk and she dropped me off on her bike at Blick, where I picked up a new can of spray paint which I used to make the orb in this day's shirt. The orb is simple yet ethereal, exploring how something so simple could be really cool. That night, I met R at the super fancy apartment she was staying at in the Financial District and we fell asleep on the couches on the roof with the most incredible view of the city.

Wanting to expand on the previous day's shirt, I turned the simple orb into a face-like shape and gave it just a shit ton of ears. Not really sure where this idea came from, but for a while I liked just drawing abstracted faces.

Another abstracted face, made with spray paint, I made this for my first day of class in my second-to-last semester in college. I really didn't like it as much as the previous day's shirt, but I wore it to class anyways because the rules I had made were the rules and I was only allowed to wear the shirt I made that day on that day. I started the daily shirt project on the last day of the previous semester, and it had been my sole focus over the summer, so beginning school was a bit scary for me in relation to how it would affect my ability to complete the project to the level I wanted to.

Continuing with the human face and figure, I spent hours drawing people all over the shirt, but was still not satisfied by the time I finished. I then made a stencil with the words "People Now" in reference to my friend Bazemore's song by the same title. I had recently made the cover art for that project as well. Go listen to People Now by Bazemore on Spotify. That night, I filled in for R at her job for Honeysuckle, where I was working as a camera assistant filming an event where there was a premiere of a docuseries the company had been working on.

On this day, I went out early with R to go rollerblading with her. Except I didn't have any rollerblades, so I just ran around with her the whole day. I had a class, but it was just online, and we smoked weed together through it, which we would do together often. We walked/rollerbladed/ran around the piers on the west side of the city and sat on the swinging benches. At one point, there was a huge ramp she wanted to skate down, so I waited at the bottom to catch her. She was going so fast down the hill and we had a huge collision and fell to the ground, which gave me a scar on my wrist that will probably never go away, and reminds me of that day often. I didn't have time to make the daily shirt until that night when I made a really ugly "Pedestrian at Best" shirt, which is a reference to another Courtney Barnett song that was one of my favorites.

This shirt features another mess of spray paint that will probably give me lung cancer, with an idea that really looked cooler in my head but was not executed so well. Sometimes, less is more. The shirt features a jagged demonic-looking figure that is walking a dog. I also really wanted a dog so badly at this point.

Originally this shirt was just going to say "sup", as in what's up, but then I didn't like it and ended up creating the "ers" and "tar" stencils as well. It looks like a food stain above the u making it a "Ãº" but its really a stain from being out at the community garden with R and getting messy with the grass and greenery. This shirt was one I really fell in love with, and I wanted to start a brand at some point, so "superstar" felt like a cool thing to rock with. I liked having these grand visions for myself, and even if I was just some regular person, thinking of myself as a superstar felt really empowering.

With the second "superstar" shirt, I began to imagine what different design elements I could incorporate to make the designs individual from one another. A rule I had throughout the project was that I wouldn't repeat the same idea. I had to come up with a new idea every day. So sticking within a specific theme I sort of broke that but certain things I would really like and try to get the most out of the idea. With the idea of a "superstar" came the idea of growth. I could not be a superstar without first growing, hence the flower.

With the third superstar shirt, I included a shadowy giant holding up a tiny star in its hand, almost contrasting the notion of a superstar being far greater than myself with the idea that there is something far greater than a superstar. This idea didn't translate so well, but I enjoyed it and was able to show up to my second week of class wearing something I was more proud of.

Continuing with the superstar idea, I made "superstar gone fishing". At a certain level, there is only so much I can write about these shirts as I was just trying to imagine all of the different iterations I could create with this shirt that I really enjoyed. Another aspect of the series I enjoyed was the mix of mediums, as I would spray paint the text and create embellishments with Posca markers.

Returning to my love of faces, I imagined a bunch of faces sticking through the letters of the superstar letters. This one might be my favorite of the superstar series, just with the colors and the motif of the faces aesthetically being really appealing to me.

This superstar shirt takes inspiration from 90's designs on like Dixie cups and McDonald's seats. At this point in the series, I am getting tired and unable to think of drastically new ideas. That is the issue of sticking with something for too long, and the value I found in continually switching up styles and trying to think of something new every day. Although I loved the superstar shirts, they began to make me stagnant.

Another abstraction of a face, but this time was done through the superstar lens. I wasn't in love with this one. It might be my least favorite of the superstar series, and at the same time, I was trying to pick up the guitar and had taken a little bit of my focus away from the shirts and toward learning the guitar. But I wasn't forced to pick up the guitar in the same way as I was forced to make the shirts. So eventually, the guitar faded out of focus and the shirts persisted.

My dad had come to New York for a work conference and I met him in Midtown. We went out to a bar, where the hostess complimented my shirt and I just said thank you. And then while I was using the bathroom my dad told her about my daily project and I get back and she asks why I didn't tell her that I made it. I guess I was already pretty tired of constantly telling people that I make my own shirt every day. That was my thing, but at the same time, I got tired of talking about it all the time. But my dad is my biggest supporter and always loves telling anyone who will listen about me and my project. I appreciate him so much for that. I am so lucky. This was another superstar shirt, which I had gotten tired of at this point but was too fried to think of anything else. This was also the beginning of NYFW, which R walked in, and she left my house that morning wearing my jacket a pair of jorts I had created, which she said she got tons of compliments on.

On this day, the final day of the superstar series, I made a naked guy you might see at Jacob Riis Beach or something. I'm not really sure what inspired this shirt exactly, other than continuing to explore the human form but in abstract ways. R had given me a ticket to watch her walk in NYFW that night, which was given to her super exclusively by one of the people in charge. At the door, they continued to reject me. My outfit was entirely free or made by me. Everyone else was dressed head to toe in designer clothes. I didn't look the part at all, and they would not let me in. This really enraged me. I felt resentment towards this system that I had dreams of being a part of the day before.

I had been strung out on the superstar series and having an incredibly difficult time coming up with new ideas, so I ended up tearing apart some old clothes that I had been holding onto just to experiment with. The whole thing is just glued together because I was too lazy and busy to sew anything, but it felt good to have a departure from the norm.

I'm not really sure where this idea came from, but it was for sure one of my favorite shirts. Classic cars and Americana are just cool motifs, and the no-u-turn sign was a reflection of where I was at in life. Something interesting about the project is that a lot of the ideas are a reflection of the project itself, where I found myself in too deep without an ability to turn back. I was fully immersed in the project, nearing the middle, and was stuck as a passenger aboard my own ride. That night, R had another show at Heaven Can Wait.

Not entirely sure what compelled me to make this lemons shirt. Sometimes you just have to find inspiration in anything. But this was my dad's last day in the city, and I really wanted him to actually meet R. We got lunch at Outro NYC where I had the most incredible chicken salad with mangos in it. R was late but met my dad and me there. We had some great conversations and my dad said he could really tell why R and I got along so well. That night, my roommate's friend A came over and we went out and got really drunk and A stayed the night with me. This marked the beginning of the end for R and I on a day when she met my dad and it went incredibly well.

This is another one of those shirts that only really exists because I needed to make a shirt that day. Maybe you could look deeper into it, with the teary eyes inside these lung forms and how weird I felt about the day before, but still, a shirt is a shirt.

This day was our friend P's birthday party, where I saw a lot of friends that I hadn't seen in a while, and I ended up making my favorite shirt I had ever made up to that point. I knew I was going to see a lot of my friends, so I wanted to make something really impressive. I spent probably 4-5 hours on this shirt and it was a big success. I got a lot of compliments. It felt so good to have my efforts rewarded and made me think about the people I wanted to create for. Illusions of grandeur at NYFW had distracted me. I had my people.

I only had a small shirt that I could hardly fit into left to wear and had an idea for some pants, so I actually spent the majority of my day working on a black and white sunflower design on a pair of jeans and putting a single sunflower on the center of the shirt. After making my favorite shirt design the day before, I was motivated to create more things that I could wear every day or whenever I wanted. But I ended up selling those sunflower jeans because I needed money.
Maybe I made this shirt to reflect on the stress that the lemon day was causing me. I'm not really sure but I guess it's a "fuck it, we ball" sort of shirt. I wanted to make something funny.

I tried to do something similar to the shirt from day 127 which was one of my favorites, but ended up making something that I really hated with a passion. Other people like this shirt more than I do, but to me, it is really terrifying. Chasing something from the past never really works out well.

I really think I created my least favorite shirt I've ever made with this one. A few years earlier, I had made my girlfriend at the time a cardboard cutout painting of this image of Childish Gambino I had recreated based on a different artist's design. I really just hated this one because it was completely unoriginal. I didn't create the original artwork. I didn't even copy the design exactly, but still, I made it look way too close to the original and did not bring any new or original aspects to it myself. This felt like I cheated or lied.

There's nothing like making an incredible shirt the day after making a shirt you hate. I was originally going to draw the building at the corner of my street on the shirt, so I went out and took some reference photography of the building, but then the stop signs in front of the building took my attention away and I decided to put those on the shirt instead. This is one of the first of the shirts where I would really begin to understand my own process, where designs would come about organically, through my own action and interaction with the world.

Yeah, sure this one is kind of ripped straight from Thrasher. But on some level I did not really care for some reason. It looked cool, and I was experimenting with how I could design the shirts outside of the level I had focused on, just smacking something on the center of the shirt. That night I went out and had fun with A and A and Z. I climbed onto the back of a garbage truck and immediately got honked and yelled at and had to not touch anything the whole way home because of the nasty grime on my hand from the truck.

I really enjoyed the idea of the straight across line design, especially for just how it falls along the arms of the body aesthetically, and I still was really in love with the shirt from day 127 so I tried to use similar colors and patterns in this design. Midway through the day, after I already finished the shirt, my brand new airbrush machine arrived. It had been a long time coming, especially for all my time working with spray paint and all of the airbrush artists recommending for me to get one. I did a quick little sketch of the design on the back and I ended up really loving how it looked. This night, I went out with a bunch of my closest friends including A, A, Z, K, S, and E. It was one of the best nights I had in a long time.

This really marks the beginning of the airbrush era of my work, which I would only really depart from on the few days when I would travel. At this point, I am just experimenting and trying to figure out what I could do with the brush. But it was pretty clear to me that this was the ultimate tool for me, as it combined the fine-line abilities of the markers with the shading and ability to cover a lot of ground that came with the spray paint. Looking back, I'm really proud of this shirt just because of the quality of brushing I had from the jump. It looks nice.

Sticking with a focus on the human form, I began to depart from the focus on the face and towards a focus on the body. Exaggerating limbs and exploring the ways the body could contort to convey certain ideas really fascinated me at this time. I was in school at this point, but I spent all my time focused on my art. In class, I would take notes but scatter them with random drawings which created a really cool collage intersecting ideas I was learning about with the ideas I wanted to pursue in my art.

I think I had drawn this design in my sketchbook during class, and it was definitely in reference to my relationship with R. I hadn't quite realized how upset she was for leaving her waiting on my stoop a few nights prior, and once I realized that it was pretty much the end I was having trouble letting go. The standing figure references R, and that's me, holding on. Later this day, I went to Union Square to interview Roots Crafts Bob, who knits hats all day perched up on a rock on the edge of the park.

This was the day of the release of Miles' album, Pressure Sensitive Butterfly Music, for which this shirt is dedicated. For weeks, this and the new Alex G album, God Save the Animals, was the only music I would be listening to. Miles' album is so romantic and beautiful, and really just an incredible piece of work. These two albums kind of consoled me as my relationship with R deteriorated, leading me to start thinking about God in an ironic yet eventually unironic way.

I looked at the work other airbrushers would create, and was inspired by the faces Austin Lee would so easily and quickly create. I tried to do that on this shirt, and ended up not really liking how it looked, and turning it into a woman because I didn't like how it looked without the hair. When R saw it she asked if it was her, which it wasn't, but she insisted I was trying to create her subconsciously. Who knows.

This one was really enjoyable just to kind of break from the norm and experiment a bit with form and function to create this crop-top with the figure sort of holding the whole thing up. This night I went to a show with one of my best friends, B, who was my roommate my freshman year. I really liked the band but I forget what they were called. They played this sort of jazz-pop-rock fusion that was really fun.

This shirt has always stood out to me as special in some sort of way. I like the purple. And the face I made and the misshapen stars. I forget what I did this day but I think it was rainy. My friend J texted me that day to tell me that my daily shirts inspired him to create a new loop on his guitar every day.

I went over to R's new Williamsburg apartment early in the morning to help her move in. I was still wearing the previous day's shirt. Her new place was nice, and she was reunited with her cat after a long time without a place to have for the cat to stay. That cat always really loved me. For some reason it was a really depressing day. I played the song "Batmobile" by Liz Phair for R and her new roommate, which probably gave them an insight to my mental state at that time. I listened to that song a lot over those past few weeks. That night I made a really messy shirt where I just continued to dislike what I had made so I just kept throwing more shit over top of itself until eventually I just had to stop.

This day, I made a stencil of a guy falling first and then didn't really like the design, so I added the words "yeah, he fell off" over top. Which, did I fall off? I had made a few shirts I really didn't like that week which had me upset. Whenever I would be making something I was less happy with, I would generally be less happy in life. When I would make shirts that I thought were really cool, I would be happy. Such is the life I forced myself into. It worked both ways. When I was more sad, I would make less cool shirts.

This one was another favorite of mine. It felt more artistic, and more designed, telling a story through this shirt with just the simple can of blue paint on the front and the figure on the back painting itself blue. I didn't do much this day, but at least I made a cool shirt. This one is an example of how my different styles evolve over time. First, I just drew tons of figures in all sorts of different positions, then I began to incorporate more elements into those figures to try to understand how I might make them more dynamic.

My first venture into some sort of biblical imagery, features two figures, one holding the other sideways to form a cross. This one is also inspired by my friend W's brand JADA, and the gun cross shirt that he sold. At school this day, I borrowed my professor's "cradle to cradle" book and took pictures of the pages that talked about nature's abundance, "ask: how can we support and perpetuate the rights of all living things to share in a world of abundance?". This class was about design and business ethics, and I was working on a project to develop a set of principles that I would use in my own practice.

This was the second time I failed to make a shirt by the end of the day, and the only time I actually went consecutive days without making a shirt. I was sick with a fever and horrible headache and unable to really eat anything for three days. I was miserable. I did my best to use at-home remedies like kombucha, ginger, juice, silver, and oreganol oil to heal myself. I was still smoking weed every day at this time, and R bought me some edibles so I could let my throat heal. I ended up having tonsillitis, which I didn't realize was a thing that adults could have or something you could have without needing to get your tonsils removed. They gave me some antibiotics but I didn't end up taking them because I didn't want to weaken my immune system. So I ended up having to make four shirts this day. This first one is pretty cool, I think.

The next shirt is a tonsillitis awareness shirt, because who the fuck gets tonsillits, like what? I was so sad that I ended up missing so many days making shirts but I needed to take the time to heal. I was in a pretty constant state of pain the entire time I was awake. I ended up missing my 9 AM capstone class that week for the second week in a row and was falling way behind. I wanted to focus on the shirts for my project, and it was rough falling behind in both areas at once.

Continuing to get into the biblical imagery or ideology, I made the love thy neighbor shirt probably just because I really appreciated that I was no longer sick and had a greater appreciation for all those around me. I ended up using this style of character in my ethics project as well.
I think I made this shirt in reference to my ethics class as well, and as I began to think more and more about the importance of protecting the planet.

The first shirt I made after finally feeling better from my tonsillitis, I guess this one is pretty similar to shirt 140 from ten days earlier. I cut it into a tank because I was still pretty sweaty and hot in general. I'm surprised I never really got into cutting the shirts into tanks over the summer.

This shirt is in reference to R, who took a few drops of oreganol oil every day, religiously, and it seemed to keep her healthy. She was super into all these natural remedies and gave me a whole list of all these strange tinctures to buy while I was sick. She ended up falling a bit under the weather as well, and nearly overdosed on oreganol oil. I'm not really sure how it works but she drank way too much of it and ended up really regretting it. I probably shouldn't have made this one, she felt made fun of for it.

Still on the huge Catholicism wave and listening to God Save the Animals constantly, I made this shirt as a funny way of being like yeah Jesus loves me. Even if I smoke or do whatever, Jesus loves me. That day I walked by a table for the Christain ministry at my school and they were like yeah come to mass with us on Friday nights. I pulled up my sweatshirt and showed them my shirt and asked if they liked it. There was a pause, and then they go "uh, yes he does." I told them I would attend mass but it was on Friday nights and I was generally busy having fun during that time so I never went.

Not really sure what exactly inspired me to make this tank, but it was another that I took from the drawings I would make in my sketchbook during class. I was beginning to focus more on school at the time, especially after falling way behind, so some days I needed the shirts to be simple and easy and take only five minutes.

This shirt holds a special place in my heart. I think it was because of the fact that I learned a few weeks later that my childhood dog, Carmen, was terminally sick with a huge tumor in her stomach. She died about two weeks after the completion of the 365 project. Carmen is a golden-colored pitbull, depicted in the upper center of this shirt. RIP Carmen. She was a great dog.

Just did whatever with the shirt, it was another day where my mental state was really reflected in the quality of the shirt. That night, B had a roof show where Miles was playing and R had promised to attend weeks earlier. After the previous night, she was no longer comfortable to come. I ended up getting drunk and super emotional at B's place, and snuck into his room to give R a call. I basically just yelled at her. We both cried over the phone. Neither of us would ever trust each other again after that point.

I felt fragile, just in a little glass box that could be crushed. I felt terrible that day, full of regret. So often, the figures in the shirts represented me in a way that I didn't always realize while making them. This one, I for sure knew that was me in that box, but a lot of other days, that wasn't so explicit in my mind. That night, I went over to S's to talk, to apologize, I'm not really sure. It was selfish of me. I was lonely. We watched a movie in her bed and I fell asleep.

I was taught how to create this flowing, morphing sort of design by my art teacher in fifth grade, when I had finished whatever sort of assignment the class was working on before everyone else did and I needed something to do. I would draw these vine-like shapes in my notebooks all the time ever since then. The one of those pieces that I had put the most work into ever now sits in my Dad's office and is his screensaver. I guess I made this as a way to return to my younger self, remind myself who I am.

Throughout the project, themes would continue to pop up. Some would appear for a whole week straight, generally apply to an entire month, or even just pop in and out every few days. I wanted to be funny with this one. Eventually that was the goal most days. Make people laugh. It feels so powerful to be wanted by Jesus. Hahaha

Oh what was this one about? I don't even know. It might have been referencing someone. Maybe I made it in reference to idealizing all these relationships in my life. Maybe I'm a figment of someone else's idealized imagination, or maybe someone else is a figment of the idealized world I made of them in my head. Maybe in reference to R, but after having a big breakdown and falling out a few nights before, I finally felt free from the grasp she held on my mind. Not going to lie, my mental state at the time still very much hinged on whether or not she was viewing my instagram stories to see my shirts.

Finalizing the holy trinity of Jesus smoking shirts, I thought it was only natural to have Jesus kills because, you know, smoking kills. Obvious link. Easy shirt. I did paint Jesus pretty well though. That day, my high school friend, Z, came to New York for his fall break to visit me and all of the guys in our friend group who were in New York. We went to Knickerbocker Bagel, and Z got a shirt from them that I airbrushed on.

Suddenly this cool gig I had as a production assistant with Honeysuckle became just terrible for me and my existence. I told S from Honeysuckle that I could work this cannabis conference, which I had seen on R's instagram that she had worked the past day. I looked at the spot she was sitting at the day before, talked to the same people she had the day before, working in the exact role that she was in the day before. When all I wanted was to not think about her, I couldn't get her out of my head. This was a long day, but I was at least able to kill two birds with one stone by writing a story for my journalism class about the event. After a long day, moving equipment all around the city and feeling generally super sad, the night ended with a party at a new dispensary in the LES on Ludlow where I ended up meeting some cool people and getting some free weed. After, I met A and S in the LES outside of A's job at Il Labritorio del Gelato and we got tacos. Then there was some guy dancing on the ground on the sidewalk right next to our table with a crowd of people cheering for him. His super masc and drunk boyfriend got all in my face because we weren't cheering and I was like "get the fuck out my face" and then the crowd had to hold him back as he screamed at me that he was going to fuck me up. Then I went home and fell asleep. I didn't end up making a shirt that day. But the next day I just made this crazy looking monster kind of thing. Again, if I'm sad, I don't have any good ideas.

The second shirt I made this day, after the mess that was the day before, was the bandaid shirt. S kept telling me that she wanted a tattoo of a bandaid and I kept being too tired to give it to her, but she inspired this shirt. I needed some healing at this time, too.

This is the day I decided to start a TikTok. For a while, people had been telling me that I would do so well on TikTok and I resisted for so long because I thought it was corny and that wasn't really my style or focus. I was making shirts to make shirts, to complete a personal journey for myself, not to get famous on social media. But a few days earlier R came over to have an end of relationship sort of talk and she showed me her ex's TikTok. He is one of those guys who just gets nearly naked and sculpts clay on a spinning wheel and talks all smooth and sexy. He has like 2 million followers or something. It was hilarious to me. I realized that there was no way I could be corny like that, and figured that I could use TikTok to sort of fill that void in my life after spending endless amounts of time thinking about R. Now I could think about TikTok or whatever! Anyways this shirt was inspired by the movie Incredibles 2, which I had watched with A and S the night before.

The last time I was working within a contained rectangle was nearly 100 days earlier, on days 92-99. Now I was returning to that contained box to make my designs. I'm not really sure where this dark creature came from, but there's something cool about him. Shrouded in darkness and scary but at the same time happy.

This shirt is made in reference to R, and how the same scenario could be looked at from both of our perspectives and we could each take away different things from it. Perception really is reality though, not only in the differences between our two perspectives but on an internal level as well. As an individual, you can take a step back from a scenario and see how, that if you look at it from a different angle, the entire scenario changes.

I had been drawing these crying faces in my sketchbook in class over the past week, but with a similar angle to the previous day. All the faces are smiling, but I drew tears on them because perception is reality. Are they happy or sad? Who knows. Maybe both. I really like this shirt. That night, K invited us to her birthday dinner at a Chinese place in Dimes Square. It was BYOB, so I picked up some sake and had a fun night with some friends. We went to the Library in the LES afterwords.

I had my 9 AM Capstone class this morning, for which I was working on a research project around uniforms. Going to private Catholic schools growing up, and now having this sort of daily uniform that was the shirt project, I found uniforms as a good way to frame my shirt project in a way that I could perform research. After class, I spent two hours standing outside of the New School's University Center taking photos of every person that walked in and out of the building, in order to try to draw similarities and understand the "uniform" of a New School Student. This was inspired by Hans Eijkelboom's "People of the 21st Century" project, and ended up producing some incredibly cool results.

After going with the cute "Dobry den" the day before, I gave the dog a gun and the words "Na shledanou" which means goodbye. My tattoo turned me evil. That day I snapped some good reference photos of some cool prints at a Charles University art museum, and at night B and I went out with the New Jersey folks to the Jazz Dock in Prague 5. I think that was the best jazz music I'd ever heard. The band was called Los Quemados.

This was the day of the big Halloween party at H's place, which was always fun and was where I had met S the year before. I decided to go as Jesse Pinkman to the party, and spent the whole day walking around looking for the perfect Jesse Pinkman hat that I could airbrush on to complete my costume. I walked about four hours to Downtown Brooklyn before finding the right hat at a TJ Max. On that mini adventure I sent R a song and we texted a bit and she sent me a text that said "i fucking love you boy", which really tortured me. Even after things were over, they weren't, and my mind was all over the place. Anyways, this shirt is inspired by those memes that are like "*jesse pinkman enduring an incredibly life-changing and trauma inducing life event*/ his shirt:". I didn't pull of the costume perfectly but it was still cool.

I made this vampire shirt to continue with the Halloween theme, as the actual date of Halloween still hadn't even happened yet. It was funny because I had gotten nothing but love on all of my shirts on TikTok until this day, when I set the video to "King Vamp" and got a bunch of hate from all these Playboi Carti fans. I never really got any hate after that, either.

This, being the actual date of Halloween, I needed to do something in the theme but was able to sort of depart from it and make something with a different message. I was doing all this work for Honeysuckle for free, and doing all this work on these shirts just to be holding onto them and not selling any, and doing all this work for school. I was broke, but maybe I'd get paid when I die. That's the struggle of an artist too. The majority of the time, someone's work won't even really be worth anything within their lifetime.

Nothing too crazy about this shirt, just some bananas. Bananas are my favorite fruit, and I was still eating a banana pretty much every day. Most of the bananas I find in Brooklyn don't have the stickers on them so I'm not sure if they are Chiquita bananas or not. I airbrushed some hats this day too.

In ethics class this week the lesson was about surveillance capitalism. "Instrumentarian power involves tracking, monitoring, and ultimately predicting human behavior". In class some kid connected the lesson with his schizophrenia and how he feels like he is always being watched. I connected it with the idea I had learned about a few years earlier, the panopticon. The panopticon is a concept for a jail in which all of the prisoners can see a central tower, but do not know when it is watching them. It can always see them, and this surveillance keeps the prisoners in place. That's what inspired this shirt.

Another day of just looking at limbs and the human form. The front features a bunch of hands reaching into the center, and the back has a bunch of feet. Nothing too special. It was another one of the days where I would have class first thing in the morning and not really have the ability to make a shirt until nighttime.

The boarding pass shirt. A classic and a return to my original form of just trying to go out into the world and confuse people or show them something they had never seen before. I made the shirt early in the morning, before my flight which ended up getting delayed so I was stuck at LaGuardia Airport for six hours. I treated myself to Shake Shack and like three beers so I got a headache from the greasiness and hangover waiting so long for my flight to finally be scheduled to leave. A TSA agent laughed at my shirt and it made me really happy.

Once I was back home in Chicago I was back to working with Posca markers for a few days, which was absolutely unbearable for me and my airbrushing obsession. But my trips home always worked well in terms of challenging me to switch things up a little. This drawing came from my sketchbook on the plane the day before. Two mirrored, intertwining bodies in an elegant dance. This day I sat out in the rain for a dreadful football game between Ohio State and Northwestern.

Only home for the weekend, I only had to make two Posca marker shirts. I thought of this one while watching my Cleveland Cavaliers beat the Los Angeles Lakers and LeBron James. Originally, it was just going to be a basketball in the middle of the shirt and say "I love basketball", but then I drew the ball off center and had to keep drawing more until I thought of this idea. Little failures throughout the process of creation often times led to even better ideas. Mistakes are amazing.

I had been dying to get back to my airbrush machine, and made something pretty mediocre but at the same time I like it because it references one of my all time favorite songs, Never Going to Die by CC Dust. On the day me, A and G moved out, we had that song playing on loop for a solid four hours and sort of gave ourselves PTSD whenever we would listen to it again. But the greatness of the song prevails and we got over it. If I were a baseball player, Never Going to Die would be my walkup song.

Thinking back to the great shirt from day 144, I wanted to do some more storytelling through the shirts. Not the best execution, but this shirt has a bomb in the corner with an explosion across the whole back of the shirt. This was also the day I set up my web store and listed a bunch of random items on there since I had just hit one thousand TikTok followers and was able to list a website in my bio.

This shirt was inspired by a tattoo I had recently seen by the artist Eden Kalif. I had been inspired by his figure drawings a lot over the course of the year, especially with some of my earliest airbrush pieces. To switch his design up and try to make it my own in some sort of way, I gave the little guy a turtleneck and hat and put some trees in the background. That day the group went out to a national music museum in MalÃ¡ Strana and I got to play some synths and look at taxadermied owls and listen to the sounds they make.

After my morning class, I went to Blick in search of stencil making materials. I was recommended mylar paper, but I didn't want something so thin and with the sticky backing. I wanted something I could reuse. I ended up finding large sheets of plastic poster board, which allowed me to trace stencils onto and were thick enough to hold together really well without tearing. Even after separating, R wanted me to make some merch for her upcoming show. The band is called "Feral Romance" so I found an image of a scary, feral looking cat and made my first stencil out of that. It took a solid hour to cut, but was well worth it. I had just unlocked a new method of creating with the airbrush.

My second airbrush stencil features an image by performance-based photographer Isabelle Wenzel, who had inspired me for a long time. I found her after researching "Leap into the Void" by Yves Klien back when I was studying photography a few years earlier. Capturing that moment of suspension was so cool to me. A moment frozen in time, with so much suspense. But I really felt like I had my head in the ground on this day, and used Wenzel's photo of that as reference. This also marked the halfway point of the project.

Oh my God I was so happy on this day. One of the happiest days of the year. I went to the Alex G concert with my friends, S, E, A, and S. I had been obsessed with Alex G's new album and was so happy to be able to go to see him live. I hadn't seen any live music all year, and really felt so personally connected and impacted by his new album. The show really lived up to my expectations. The back of the shirt reads "Alex G saved me from eternal damnation" because the whole album was centered around God and family. These Americana sort of themes would have a major influence on my work throughout the rest of the project.

I was just searching anywhere and everywhere for inspiration, and had a ton of images to reference from all the books I had bought the year before when I was really into making collages. This image is from a book about Greek or Roman statues or something. I don't really remember.

Out of thin air, Elf Bars were seemingly everywhere. Everyone walking down the street would just be puffing on these Elf Bars. The company rebranded to EBDesign, so RIP Elf Bar. But yeah Elf Bars had gotten just as bad as the rats in New York and that's what inspired this shirt. This was my first TikTok that really blew up and I was flooded with comments and DMs asking if I was selling the shirt.

I really like doing little tryptic series, so this is the second of three rat shirts. RIP Henny rat, NYC icon. Fly high buddy. I remember making this because I thought it would have a lot of wide-spread appeal.
