This day was the start of the strike at the New School, which cut out the whole final third of the semester after the professors went on strike because the school wasn't paying them enough and was firing professors right when they were about to hit tenure just so they wouldn't have to pay them more. The New School was supposed to be the most progressive school in the nation and it was just so incredibly surprising that they operate just like a big business. This was the final of the three rat shirts in a row, inspired by the giant inflatable rats that they have at strikes.

This was the day of R's release party that she had been planning for a few months, back when we were still together. She had texted me earlier that week about how important it was that I come. But she posted the lyrics to the song a few days earlier, with some lyrics referencing specific things I told her when we had our breaking up conversation. The song was called "Bitch Boy". Lol. So embarrasing. I made some merch for her too! So embarrassing. So my shirt of the day just had a little boy watering some flowers on the front, and on the back there is a big red target, like through the scope of a gun. You can put the pieces together. I didn't even realize how angry I was until I got there and saw her. We hugged and talked outside for a few minutes as we shared a joint. Some other guys there with us tried to sell me shrooms. Then I went to give the pieces I made to this other guy who was running the merch for the show. He was a dick, ignoring me and treating me like I was inferior. It wasn't the first time he'd brushed me off like that either, and I decided I was done being treated like that. I went up to R and told her I was leaving. She said she thought that was a good idea, and squeezed my wrist. I squeezed her wrist back, and threw it away. Then I walked out and never saw her again. Down the street, light and music shone out from a ground-floor church. I pulled open the heavy door, and a woman asked if I knew that the service was a Pentecostal Dominican mass, fully in Spanish. I said yes, I wanted to enter. I found a chair near the back, and sat through 45 minutes of beautiful music and prayers. I watched, listened, and cried. Throughout the service a toddler crawled around, babbling baby noises and banging on a tambourine he had found. I walked out probably just a few minutes before the mass was ending, and went home where I demanded that A go out with me. We went to Bossa Nova, where we got drunk, danced, and asked strangers for poppers, before capping the night with some OMG Burger Pizza.

One of the only things keeping me going was the fact that I could watch a new episode of White Lotus every Sunday. Obviously Jennifer Coolidge was absolutely iconic throughout her run on that series and I knew I needed to make a shirt with her in it. American Girl Boss. Also, that morning, I randomly started listening to "softCORE" a new album by FousheÃ©, who was an artist I had never listened to before. In some sort of crazy spiritual way, it felt like I had written that album. I was in love with it. S came over that night and and I gave her the band-aid tattoo she had been asking me for. It was the worst tattoo I have ever given. Then I went to Ridgewood to pregame before going to Basement with V, C, J, A and others.

Nothing like an entire day in bed to bring you back to earth after a fun night out. That morning, V and I ubered back from Basement to her place in Flatbush as the sun rose. We then stayed in bed the entire day, past the sunset. I was exhausted and needed the rest, but was stressing out the entire time about the fact that I would have to make my way back into the city and then back into Brooklyn to make my shirt that night. But my friend B was hosting a rooftop show in Chinatown, so I decided I wasn't ready to go home yet. Walking a mile in the freezing cold to get to the show, I screamed out lyrics to "simmer down", "i'm fine", "bored", and others off FousheÃ©'s new album. I must have looked so crazy, singing and rocking sunglasses at night with a delirious smile smacked across my face. The wind on that Chinatown rooftop was insane and I only stayed about half an hour before making my way home. S and A were home, and I wanted to just chill on the couch with them, but I forced myself to make the "BE OK" shirt, which features a bald-headed guy similar to the ones I tattooed on my legs on New Years Day at the beginning of that year. I was going to be ok.

The other night, I was talking to some of the people who I was going to Basement with about my shirt project, and about an idea I had for a stairmaster shirt. I felt like I was on an infinite stairmaster, both with the shirt project and in my relationships. A gave me some great advice, first being that I should not wash the shirts before selling them, and second to put Jesus on the stairmaster. Brilliant. I typically didn't take anyone's ideas or suggestions because I wanted the project to be fully my own, but her idea was just too good and I decided to rock with it. Also, not washing the shirts meant some of them would be pretty grimey and stained and gross, but washing them would remove that essential and real part of the story.

On this day, my new projector arrived, which would drastically change and evolve my method of creation. On a certain level the projector made it feel like I was cheating, but using a projector is actually pretty common practice among airbrushers and was well worth it as I was able to start creating things that I really and truly loved wearing. In the morning, A and I went to the park to bury G's fish, Ciao, which had died earlier that week. I teared up as we buried him next to a root beneath the base of a tree. This week involved a lot of change. For my first projected shirt, I painted my little sister C's bed. It was covered in dozens of stuffed animals and I knew it would be such a cool thing to paint, but I knew I couldn't do it the way I wanted to without the projector. I love C so much. And although I was going through my roughest stretch of the entire year, I was making things I loved.

After honoring my sister C on the previous day's shirt, I wanted to do the same for my sister K, so I painted one of my favorite photos of her where she is holding a baby lamb and has the most beautiful and ecstatic smile on her face. I posted both shirts honoring my sisters to my instagram, and later that day R blocked me. I guess she didn't want to see my shirts anymore. But that really hurt, it made me so sad. I loved her so much at one point, and then I found myself completely blocked out of her life. It was probably for the best though. I needed to get her out of my head.

Keeping with tradition, I made another boarding pass shirt for my flight to Cleveland for Thanksgiving. I brought along the previous two days shirts with me too so I could show them off to my family. This shirt also marks an introduction to a new freestyle font style I would begin working in, with large exaggerated serifs contrasted with skinny stems. But every time I tried to replicate that font style I felt like I was chasing this first time I did it, which I still feel was the best rendition of that lettering.

This shirt was made on Thanksgiving as I sat at my Grandma's dining room table. She told me, "oh Jack, you are just so talented." I really love Grandma Audrey so much. Every time I talk to her she hypes me up so much and is just the sweetest person I know.

In the morning, my cousins, grandparents, parents and sister C and I went to breakfast at a local diner near my grandparents house. I was really lost for ideas, and didn't end up making a shirt until that night, when I watched the movie Suspiria with my cousins and made one of my one-line drawings. R really loved that movie and I was just trying to get over her so it was an uncomfortable watch. She would call herself a witch and that's basically what the movie is about. Kinda some scary mystical shit.

The whole extended family got together to celebrate Thanksgiving and watch the Ohio State- Michigan game. I made the "family" shirt just because I was out of ideas and really felt that there was nothing more important than being with my family. It was a little bittersweet though because my sister K wasn't able to make it on the trip. When I hugged my Grandma Audrey goodbye, she said "oh Jack, you just give the best hugs." I think about that often. Some hugs are different when you really love someone.

Dean Blunt had just released his new song called "death drive freestyle" and I listened to it on my way back to my apartment from the airport. Its such a beautiful song and I wanted to send it to like five different people but the lyrics were just too deep and sad so I just kept it to myself and played it on a loop for hours while I made a shirt with the cover art. The original photo is of girls covering their faces from police tear gas at a straightedge concert, which is a subgenre of punk that refrains from using alcohol, tobacco, and drugs in reaction to the excesses of punk subculture.

I never really fell in love with music until 2016, when I first heard Lil Uzi and became obsessed. He was so cool to me. I could listen to his music with whatever mood I was feeling. When I was happy, I danced and turned up to his music. When I was sad, I could cry to it. Anyways, on this day I learned that his iconic heart-eyes Meowth jean jacket was airbrushed and I knew I had to do a piece to honor it. That night, H came over and we smoked a joint and talked as I airbrushed the shirt. Later on, I went out to S and E's place and we drank wine and watched The Room.

Wow. I reached day 200. The first hundred days felt like they could have been an entire year and the second hundred went by in the blink of an eye. It was getting easier and easier to make my shirts, really becoming second nature. This day had to be something special, so I went with the phrase "everything is important", coming from the idea I had for the name of a brand I was planning on launching. The name is way too long, but I still plan on sticking with it. There's something striking about the name. It really means something to me, and is something that I think speaks to the project and my outlook on art as a whole. There is beauty in everything. This night, I also submitted all of the paperwork I needed to finalize my January study abroad in Prague.

I spent a while figuring out what to make this day, and ended up making one of my favorite pieces I had ever done. This was actually maybe the only one that I went back to and revised a few days after finishing it, adding the light blue outline to really make the whole design pop. Now that I was projecting images to airbrush onto my shirts, I would spend a lot of my time either taking reference photography or looking back through my camera roll to find images. A year back from making this shirt, I had worked on my close friend G's film and was a pall bearer. We shot in a church, and I took a bunch of photos of all the random cool religious imagery in there. I don't believe in organized religion, but there was something spiritual about working on that film in that church, and something spiritual about making the shirt too.

Some days don't have any sort of deeper meaning and are just shirts that I made because I thought they looked cool. I tried to make this shirt as photo-realistic as possible, which is funny to reflect on because it is nothing compared to what I would be able to do now. But it's cool to see how far I've come, and its still a nice ass shirt if you ask me. That night, S and E came over and we played headbands which would become a favorite passtime of ours.

This shirt was a long time coming, being a favorite inside joke between A and I for a while, from our favorite show, Nathan for You. All the time either of us could just say "so sorry I died" and the other would crack up laughing. Later in the year, about two weeks after the 365 project ended, my family's dog, Carmen, passed away. I still haven't fully processed it. The first night we got her, she slept at the foot of my bed and kept me up all night because she was under the weather and was breathing all crazy. She was a great dog. RIP Carmen.

Growing up, I loved PokÃ©mon so much. It was probably my favorite obsession. After hanging out with my extended family the week before, I learned that pretty much all of my cousins love PokÃ©mon, no matter how old each of us are. Lapras is one of the coolest ones in my opinion, so I put it on my shirt this day. Later, my friends and I went out to the city for whatever reason and got drinks at 212 Hisae. We walked past the gallery where I had displayed my weed bag collages back on day 35 of the project, and Tito shouted out my name.

King of The Hill is probably the greatest animated show ever made. I wish I had done a better job centering the text on this one but you get the point. Lol. This night I went on a date with some girl from Hinge and to be honest I really didn't feel like going and I wasn't into her at all but I went anyways and still had a good time. This one guy in the band we saw looked smack like Christopha from the Sopranos.

In my signature font, I quote A's childhood video of him going "hi hi hiii" and yeah its just a really cute video. Also on this day A (different A) and D moved out just all of the sudden. I liked having A and D as roommates because they were cool people but it was strange living with them because they would leave for weeks at a time and then come back at random times. It got lonely having just one other roommate a lot of the time. This day I went on a second date with the girl who I saw the band with and then felt pretty bad because I went over to her place and then just acted really awkward and said I had to go and never texted her again.

This was an idea that had come to me right when I woke up a few days earlier. I just pictured some girl from like the 50's or whenever talking through a landline phone and yeah that's what the shirt ended up being for this day.

I had been listening to a bunch of Indigo De Souza songs after finding her song "Take Off Your Pants" on my discover weekly a few months earlier. This shirt is inspired by her song "How I Get Myself Killed", which had been playing through my head a lot. It's not like the shirt project is actually how I would get myself killed unless I put something really crazy on the shirt but maybe it was the fact that I was depressed or something I'm really not quite sure. Maybe the shirts would drive me to madness and I would kill myself. Well obviously that didn't happen because I'm writing this right now and I survived the 365 days. I beat the shirts. Imagine dying in this shirt though. This is probably the best shirt to get yourself killed in. This night S, A, A and I all snuggled up in my bed and watched Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Rodrick Rules, projected up onto my bedroom wall.

At 7 in the morning I was aboard the 2 train going all the way to the Upper West Side to load camera equipment into a car for S from Honeysuckle. I don't even think I got paid for this job, and I didn't get any free weed either so it kinda sucked. I just helped out shooting product shots for some rich white lady's new dispensary. It was pretty cool being in her fancy house in Prospect Park South, especially after hanging around that area before and having no idea that there were suburban-ass houses less than a mile from the regular Flatbush apartments I had been in a few weeks earlier. I got the best chicken curry I've ever had that day from a place called Cafe Madeline, which was the only thing that made it all worth it. I just kinda messed around on the shirt when I got home and really didn't like what I made, so I wrote "I hate it" on it. That night was Keyframe, an animation show that my friend S had work in along with a bunch of other people who would become my friends later on.

So I got up at 8 and in a daze took an uber to the camera rental place, which was back down in the Prospect Park area again. I then wandered around the area, eventually making my way to the park and walked around there all hazy and disoriented but happy. I went for a run in my jeans that I wear every day and then went to the Brooklyn Public Library and took one of the biggest poops of my life. I sat in the library and read my book, The Art Spirit by Robert Henri, for ten minutes until I got bored and left. Then I went to Blick to pick up some more paint before heading home. I was so fried off the four hours of sleep I got and still managed to make my "Your Ad Here" shirt. This one was inspired by my TikToks getting bigger and random people reaching out to me to try to get me to put whatever images they wanted on the shirts. But they clearly did not understand me, like come on. This is art. Not some sort of promotional thing. That's why I avoided social media for the longest time. Because although the project seems so social media-oriented, that's really not the point of the project whatsoever. That night I went out to Le Bain for E's birthday and I did not have a very good time, probably because I was so dead from the night before, but also just because Le Bain sucks.

The importance of sleep on my mental well-being can not be understated. Days where I wake up at like noon feeling gross and sweaty really set me back, often for weeks at a time. Despite feeling grimy and exhausted, I made this Tommy Wiseau "The Room" shirt to honor the film. I really just wanted to make something that was funny and that a bunch of people would enjoy. I had actually met Tommy Wiseau a few years earlier and I own a pair of underwear with his name on them because you had to buy something in order to get a picture with him.

I waited until the 11th hour to make this shirt and I think it shows, but a lot of times people end up really liking these shitty throwaway ones. I made it the new blank street coffee uniform as well, because people kept talking about how new blank streets kept popping up everywhere. But I guess I'm not really in the gentrified area because I hadn't ever seen one before.

Finally, the New School's strike had ended and I had class again, even though it was just one single class in the last week of the semester. This shirt ended up being somewhat iconic in my life because it really blew up on the clock app, reaching 1.8 million views. I was happy to get attention, but at the same time it sucked having this be the one that blew up. I felt like I was the face of the strike in a way that was kind of scary. I didn't want everyone who I went to school with and used TikTok to know who I was and what I was doing. This day I had a great time though because E's studio class had an exhibition and I went with my friends and got pretty wine drunk and had fun looking at art before leaving my friends to go to my final journalism class.

Where's your head at????? Where's your head at? Yeah this one is inspired by this song by Basement Jaxx and is a real nice one to dance to. V showed it to me on the night of the Halloween party a few months earlier and it had stayed in rotation ever since. This night I went with A, S, E, and S to the Times Square Olive Garden because we thought it would be a nice time. Which, it was, other than the fact that the food was about twice as expensive as we expected it to be. The bottomless breadsticks were nice, though, and so was going to the Disney store and the big Christmas tree in Rockafeller Plaza.

The year before, I had gotten very into collaging as my main medium and gathered about 50 books and magazines over the course of a few months. Sometimes I would spend up to $20 on a single book because I was so in love with it, and I would hold onto it and make sure no one would cut it apart, but most of the books I bought were just whatever I could find with cool or interesting images for $2. This image of the "homunculus" comes from one of those bargain books about the key poses of hatha yoga. The homunculus is apparently scales the human body to the number of nerve endings in that part of the body.

This shirt is made in honor of the huge stuffed bear I got from my grandparents' house over Thanksgiving. After making the shirt with the dozens of stuffed animals stacked on my sister's bed, I really wanted my own stuffed animals in my room and my grandma offered up the bear my uncle had won in an art competition at the grocery store back in the 80s. After 40 years, he never claimed it, so the vintage bear was mine. The fact that it is day 216 is special because that is also Cleveland's area code. This day I also shipped out about 6 items of clothing that I sold through my website after my TikTok blew up a few days earlier.

Of course, this shirt is absolutely iconic. Nothing much to say here, you know what's going on. This was my second full-color portrait. That night, I went out to Golden Years with my friends. Golden Years is traditionally known for playing Kanye music so it was interesting to see what they would play as Kanye had just been fully cancelled for praising Hitler among other crazy shit. They ended up playing a bunch of songs that Kanye sampled and Hannah Montana by the Migos. RIP Takeoff. We met some french guys that night that were rooting for France in the World cup.

Messi and Argentina had won the World Cup and I knew I had to do something to honor him. I had been thinking about the idea of a knockoff jersey for a while, or just jersey design in general and how it could be funny or a nice commentary to replicate or make bootleg airbrush versions of jersey designs that I thought were cool. So this video had been circulating online of Messi acting super awkward around this supermodel lady and the people on the internet were trying to use it as proof that Messi had autism. That's really kind of besides the point other than the fact that I resonate with Messi and if Messi has autism then I have autism too.

This shirt is inspired by the daily grind of eating. I was just pissed off that my body would get hungry every day and that I would have to go outside and buy food from the deli or ingredients from the grocery and just work to supply my body with energy. I enjoy food, but at the same time life would be so much easier some days if I didn't need to eat to survive.

Bonjour Kitty! This one was inspired by a girl who was really pretty and would like my instagram stories and had a hello kitty profile picture. I probably shouldn't have made this shirt, or at least I should have DMed her at some point but I never ended up doing that and she just became yet another person who I only knew through the internet and eventually would pretty much forget about. That happened a lot throughout the year. For some reason I am just uncomfortable with sliding into somebody's DMs. Also when I was young I would have these vivid nightmares where Hello Kitty would stab me to death in some sort of creepy cartoon realm. This was my last day in New York for a while before leaving for the holidays and going to Prague for the month of January, which made me uncomfortable and stressed out all day.

Continuing the tradition of the boarding pass shirt, this one is inspired by food wrappers and advertisements. I was unsure of how I would be able to make my shirts without my airbrush machine after getting home to Chicago, so I had to make this one bright and early in the morning at around 7AM before leaving for the airport.

Another song-inspired shirt, this one is inspired by the Pixies' "Monkey's Gone to Heaven". The back features the entirety of the Nicene Creed, which I would recite in mass every Tuesday growing up and going to a Catholic middle school. My mom told me she would be giving me a portable airbrush machine for Christmas and I convinced her to give it to me early so I could make this day's shirt. The brush and compressor were both terrible and definitely affected the quality of this shirt and the shirts that I would make over the coming month.

A major reason that I cannot see myself living in Chicago anytime soon is the weather. This shirt depicting a dead tree is inspired by the -3 degree fahrenheit temperature of the day. I was kinda pissed all day because my mom forced me to get a Covid booster and every time received a Covid shot I ended up being sick and bedridden for the entire next day. It's not like I'm anti-vax or anything like that either, but I managed to make it through the pandemic without getting Covid once and I just had this feeling that I was immune to it and it was pointless to feel sick for an entire day, but I did it anyways and bought my new favorite pair of glasses at the CVS.

For Christmas Eve, I made the Stevie Wonder version of Snoopy because he looked super chill and my mom surrounds the house with Peanuts-themed decor for the holidays. My family also has a tradition of gifting pajamas on Christmas Eve, so I airbrushed my mom a sweatshirt of Snoopy and Charlie Brown holding hands and dancing.

For the anniversary of Whole Lotta Red release day, I made a piece honoring the greatest musician to ever live. My portable airbrush machine finally gave in and broke this day, so I ended up hand-painting the whole thing with a paintbrush. The family spent the day driving to Cleveland to spend the holidays with the extended family. For Christmas I gifted my sisters shirts with their favorite PokÃ©mon on them.

My birthday! It's always been weird having my birthday be the day after Christmas because I have almost never been able to spend the day with my friends or going out and doing anything super fun. But I still love it, and I love being able to spend the day with my extended family who are the real ones and will always celebrate me. For my birthday I got a new Iwata Eclipse brush, which meant I would be able to continue airbrushing with my whack ass compressor. I was happy. This shirt has a quote about Capricorns and capricorn season that I feel encapsulates me and my vision for the project as a whole.

I convinced my parents to stay in Cleveland a little longer for the morning so we could go to breakfast at Bob Evans with the cousins. Classic Ohio activities. We then drove to Dayton to visit my mom's parents who live there. This shirt was pretty random and uninspired. I don't know what I was thinking with the pink stars like how did I not realize that they would look like Patrick. Idk.

I made plans with my friends that night to go bowling at night, and made this shirt in the morning in Dayton before the long trek back to Chicago. We stopped in Fishers, Indiana on the way home to visit our cousins. Fishers is a funny place. Whenever I think about it I remember my friend Obakes saying that its "a factory of white people". I saw Obakes and about 10 other friends from high school that night. I got really drunk and bowled horribly.

I made this shirt in honor of the queen Vivienne Westwood, who died on this day. I watched a documentary on her and she seemed really mean but at the same time I have such a huge appreciation for her and her work. RIP to a legend.

Nothing too crazy inspired this design. I just like cats and like how this looks. I had been thinking a lot about the spherical shading that I thought I did really well with on the bowling shirt and that's part of what inspired me to make this. Looking at it now though, I got pretty lazy with the shirts for a lot of days. Now I would likely add some black shading and white highlights to really add that depth. My dad had his last day of work at the company he had worked at for ten years on this day, and we went out to a steakhouse to celebrate but he stayed too late at work so we ended up just eating without him and ordering a steak for him to eat at home.

When I moved away for college in 2019, my sister took the liberty of decorating my new room (her old room) with my collection of PokÃ©mon cards. It's a cool vibe in my new room. The cards cover a whole wall and are a little overwhelming to look at but are also so cool to look at. The jigglypuff card and my feeling of existential dread inspired this shirt. There's something about going out and having fun that always leaves me feeling drained and sad the next day. That's why I've never taken molly.

New Year's resolutions are bullshit. Sort of. Just make resolutions when you need to. Always be thinking ahead and making changes where you see fit. But yeah I saw myself on a path of growth and did not feel like there were any specific changes I needed to make to my life. I am perfect and delusional. And just trying to be funny. For the first day of 2023 I had a flight to Frankfurt, Germany and then on to Prague, Czech Republic from there. Before my flight I got drunk at the Chicago airport Chili's and met a couple from Iowa who were moving to Germany. I slept and listened to Alex G for nearly the entire flight.

After boarding my flight from Chicago on the first I finally landed in Prague on the second at night, and immediately made this shirt in the bathroom of my hotel room. I probably should have just went to sleep right then but I ended up staying up until like 2AM wandering around the touristy areas of Prague and hitting up Czech girls on Tinder, trying to get someone to come over to no avail.

I woke up and made this fucked up emoji shirt as a representation of how I was feeling being in a foreign country. I already felt completely out of place, even though part of the reason I knew I had to go to Prague was that my family came to the US from Czechoslovakia, but on the Slovak side. After making the shirt in the shower of the bathroom, I took an overpriced taxi over to the Universitia Karlova dormitories in Prauge 6. I met my roommate for the next three weeks, B, and the eight other students who were in the Prague API study abroad program.

Nowadays I would spend probably like two hours on this shirt and it would turn out beautiful. But something you have to understand about the daily shirt project is that I did not have two hours every day to dedicate to a shirt. Sometimes I only had 20 minutes. So for this one I was just going to have a person picking their nose, but then I made it look ugly and blue so I turned it into an Avatar 2 shirt. I still haven't seen that movie because nobody wants to spend three hours of their life watching it with me but that's cool. I feel like this shirt probably does a good job summing it up. On this day I took the 22 tram with the class down to Charles University to get my school ID and walk around and chill in the touristy area of Prague 1.

Prague is known as the city of 100 spires, even though nowadays there are probably over a thousand spires. Anyways, "Prague: Get InSPIREd". That night I went on the trip to the underground communist bunker in Å½iÅ¾kov, which was built by the Russians to protect the city from potential nuclear war back when they controlled Prague during the Cold War. Prague has a crazy history, much of it very recent, which is cool yet jarring to see. Jana, the director of our small study abroad program, told us stories about growing up under the communist regime and attending protests and fighting for her freedom, and she's only in her forties.

Walking up the hill to get to my dorm in Prague 6, I would pass a marionette shop with this cat doll in the window that would always strike me. Prague is apparently known for its marionettes, and while in Prague I wanted my art to focus as much on the local culture and traditions as possible. So the night before, I had taken a reference photo of the doll and made the shirt this morning. Later in the day, I decided to break off from the study abroad group to go to the shop and show the old lady who worked there my shirt, as well as ask her to take a picture of me with the doll. She was really kind, despite the language barrier, even though she was probably really confused.

In my opinion, this is the best shirt I made during my time in Prague. There's a few others I like too but I'm happy with how well I was able to replicate a drawing from the communist bunker freehand, both in terms of the quality of the airbrushing and the accurate proportions of the drawing. After falling asleep at like 4AM the night before, B and I had to wake up at 7 to catch the tram and subway to the spot where we would be leaving for a trip to ÄŒesky Krumlov. We ended up waking up too late for the tram and had to catch an uber to where we needed to go, but it was so worth it. The uber was only like 7 dollars and turned a 45 minute trip into like 15. I caught up on my sleep on the bus. ÄŒesky Krumlov was one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen.

Going back to back with the Prague Spring-inspired shirts, I made this based on a poster I saw in the communist bunker a few days prior. My fatal flaw is not being able to center text or write it straight. Shirt still goes hard though. I spent the majority of this day sleeping and recovering before going out to an arcade bar in NovÃ© MÄ›sto, Prague 2, at night.

For this shirt I recreated a beer label depicting John of Nepomunk, who the Catholics were pushing as a martyr to the Czech people, who really didn't like the Catholics. Back in the 14th century, the Czech people were on the side of the Protestants and looked at Jan Hus, who was burned at the stake, as a holy martyr for the Protestant cause. But once the Catholics took over power they began pushing for John of Nepomuk, who was thrown of Charles Bridge and into the river, to replace Jan Hus in a symbolic manner. While in Prague I was taking a course on Czech history so yeah I learned all about this stuff. This day was spent visiting the VyÅ¡ehrad Cemetary, where a bunch of famous Czechs were buried and I got tons of really good reference photos of statues that I would later airbrush once I was back in New York.

In Czech, "Dobry den" means "hello" or "good day". And in Prague, a bunch of people own dogs and I would see them on the trams every day so I thought this would be a nice cute little thing to honor Prague's love of dogs. On this day I also lined up a tattoo session in Prague 5 and spent most of my day focused on that. I had found the artist online before going to Prague and was so excited for this tattoo and getting something that could always remind me of my time in Prague. At the time of my tattoo, the artist went by the name "self harm tattoo" which is pretty wild lol but I guess she got some advice and has since switched it up to "symbolism tattoo".

After going with the cute "Dobry den" the day before, I gave the dog a gun and the words "Na shledanou" which means goodbye. My tattoo turned me evil. That day I snapped some good reference photos of some cool prints at a Charles University art museum, and at night B and I went out with the New Jersey folks to the Jazz Dock in Prague 5. I think that was the best jazz music I'd ever heard. The band was called Los Quemados. I ate hummus and drank the only overpriced beers I had in Prague.

This shirt was inspired by a tattoo I had recently seen by the artist Eden Kalif. I had been inspired by his figure drawings a lot over the course of the year, especially with some of my earliest airbrush pieces. To switch his design up and try to make it my own in some sort of way, I gave the little guy a turtleneck and hat and put some trees in the background. That day the group went out to a national music museum in MalÃ¡ Strana and I got to play some synths and look at taxadermied owls and listen to the sounds they make. That night, my best friend A arrived from Lisbon, where he was studying abroad at the same time as I was in Prague.

I made this shirt in a rush after getting home late and having a terrible sleep on the floor, leaving for class last minute and having A clean out my airbrush. This one is obviously inspired by the best jazz of my life on the Jazz Dock a few days earlier. At the end of class, we went to the Czech National Museum and I spent a lot of time in the crystal room, where A met me. They had literally thousands of the craziest different rocks and crystals I've ever seen. It was a spiritual/energy type of girlie's wet dream. It was pretty cool though. The energy was different in that room.

I didn't have time to break out my airbrush machine and make a shirt in the morning before the bus to Berlin, so I just packed three blank white shirts, a sharpie, and hoped for the best. All of Germany was a blur. We managed to make it by train from the bus depot into Scheunenviertel, where we stayed at the St. Christopher Inn Alexanderplatz. The hostel had a sports bar beneath it that we used as a general meeting spot. Staying at the hostel also meant we got discounts on food and drinks, which helped but it was still overpriced from the start. It was a harsh reminder of my reality going from $2 Czech beers that were the best drink I'd ever had to the $8 Americanized German beers. That night, B, A and I ordered round after round of Long Island Iced Teas and Jager Bombs as I made my German-inspired shirt while sitting at the bar.

Like I said, my three days in Berlin were a whole blur. Living in the hostel and never getting any ounce of personal space is stressful. At least one person would be asleep in the room we stayed in for 24 hours a day, so I had to be quiet whenever I was in that dark room. We went out for brunch around 2 in the afternoon and I had some incredible oatmeal. Next I made the shirtception shirt and we went out for a long walk to Friedrichshain. On our way, we wandered past this crazy huge building which I was pretty sure was Berghain. It was, and the line was really short so we decided to say fuck it why not just hop in line and see if we could get in.

This, our last day in Germany, was a rather slow and dazed recovery day. I watched NFL playoff highlights on the sports bar TVs as A left for his flight back to Lisbon. Before our bus back to Prague, B and I wandered around Berlin for a bit, visiting the Holucaust Memorial and the huge park that sits next to it. The bus terminal was extremely cold and bleak. A light sheet of snow covered the ground in Prague. I made the shirt in sharpie again after getting back to the dorm around 1 AM. It is inspired by an Aaron Rogers shirt.

This shirt is inspired by some graffiti I had seen the previous day in Berlin. On the back, I just freestlyed a skull and a cross and it ended up looking pretty cool. At the Czech history class, the instructor was pretty pissed at B and I for missing the previous day being in Berlin. Czechs are very proud of their identity and the professors took it as almost a slight to their culture that we missed our time in Prague for the allure of Berlin. I assured them that I liked Prague far more than Berlin. At the end of class we went to a Czech military museum and saw all this cool old military stuff. That night, B and I went out again to Necropolis, our favorite bar, and stayed until closing before making it back to the dorm and chilling and laughing in our room for a few hours.

This morning I was the only one to attend Jana's guide through a museum on the history of Prague. I felt kind of silly being the only one there but I was in love with Jana and needed to make up for my time missed in Berlin so it was definitely worth it. After the Czech history class, we visited a Church where Czech soldiers fighting against the Nazis hid out after a successful assassination mission on Reinhard Heydrich, the principal architect of the Holocaust, before finally being killed in the basement. One of the families to help the soldiers was the Moravec family, which is my Grandmother's maiden name. I felt connected to the right side of an important piece of history. That night I made my first starry-eyed skeleton shirt, inspired by drawings I would do during class time to keep myself from falling asleep. That night, we went out to a bar in Old Town Square and had a nice night.

This, being my last official day with the group in Prague, I had to make a shirt to honor the city. I wanted to go to a tourist shop to buy an I heart Prague sweatshirt but I never got the time. For our final class, the group went out to VÃ­tkov hill. I wish I spent more time in that area of Prague. It looks cooler and more artist-friendly. That night, we had a farewell dinner with all of the professors and guides. I ate my final goulash and drank some of my final Czech beers. I don't think we went out that night. Everyone except for me had to wake up early for their flights home the next morning.

On my final day in Prague, I went to breakfast one last time and said farewell to all of the other students on the trip with me. Finally, being alone in that dorm room, I felt a rush of anxiety and sadness. I don't think my time in Prague was all I initially imagined it would be. I loved all of my time there, but was left with this profound feeling that I had failed to achieve what I had initially set out to accomplish being there, despite entering with no actual goals with my time. I was sad that my time in Prague so quickly came to a close and even more sad that I didn't enjoy it more. I made my way to a hotel next to the airport to stay in for the night before my flight in the morning. At the hotel, I planned to airbrush and make the most out of my final hours in Prague but I ended up smoking the rest of the weed I had bought and kind of just doing nothing and crashing early. I did get a nice dinner though and got to have my final Pilsner Urquell, which is the best beer ever made.

For this shirt I had my entire flight back from Prague through Geneva and back to New York to think about it and I was so excited to finally get back to my nice airbrush compressor with my new Iwata brush to make something I would be really proud of. It turns out I was a little rusty. I had been ruminating on ideas around hydration for the past week and I guess this is what came out of it. On the front it says something like, "I'm a glass all the way full sort of person", and on the back I just threw up the Poland Springs logo because of that Lil Yachty song. Also, for the record, Poland Springs water is great and I don't really get why go for the Essentias and Figis of the world.

Given more time to think, plan, and experiment on this shirt than I had for the entire past month, I made something that I liked quite a lot. Not really sure what inspired this other than maybe the phrase "Gone Fishing!". I think that might be a good name for a brand.

Wow, this is a clusterfuck of a shirt. I had really enjoyed the piece I made the day before and wanted to do something similar with just the profile of a face, but then I didn't really like what I had made so I just kept adding shit to it until it resembled something that I like. I probably did a little too much with this one but it was a nice little brain dump of ideas I would continue to explore with later shirts.

I had continued to draw star-eyed skeleton after star-eyed skeleton in my sketchbook and wanted to make another shirt with my little buddy/character I had created. Originally, the skeleton was going to be holding something but then I kind of ran out of space and didn't want whatever he was holding to be in the armpit of the shirt. This day, I had my first class of the new semester, my final semester of college. For some reason the scheduling on my classes got super weird so I ended up having this one online. It was probably worth it having the class online so I could spend more time focusing on my shirts and not have to go outside early in the day, but at the same time I loved being at school and just running into random friends. I will miss it.

This shirt might seem like its kind of just a bullshit shirt because I didn't really do anything on it. Maybe it is, but anyways I was diving deeper into religious imagery inspired by my time in Prague and spent my entire class that day writing and drawing ideas for all the things I would make. And at the end of the day, those ideas looked a little too ambitious. But the shirt I was going to paint on already had a few specks of paint on it, and something about that felt important or spiritually significant in some sort of way. I needed a break, and I was given one. Some days I just liked the look of a blank white shirt better anyways.

This shirt was inspired by a far more grand and time consuming idea for a shirt I had come up with in class the day before. I wanted to make a halftone stencil with literally thousands of dots that I would individually cut out to reveal a distorted image of Mary holding Jesus. I spent about three hours this day individually drawing each of the dots onto the stencil before realizing that there was no way I would complete this stencil in time to make the shirt of the day, so I made a far more simplified version of Mary holding Jesus with a sort of pop art advertisement spin on it.

I was inspired by sports jersey designs for some reason and eventually came up with this. On the back it says something like "Sports!". I was getting more into ringer tees and liked being able to make my own bootleg ones by painting the collars around the neck and sleeves.

Still enjoying the ringer tee look, I was inspired by the funny ass stickers I had bought in Moab, Utah back when I was in the first week of making my own shirt every day. I got like 8 incredibly redneck stickers ironically but never had anything to put them on so they just ended up sitting around on my desk for eight months until I finally took inspiration to make a shirt.

This is another shirt inspired by ringer tees and the redneck stickers I bought in Utah. It was fun trying to replicate the font, even if I didn't do it perfectly. This night I went down to Flatbush to link with this girl T who had found my TikTok and wanted to work together. She does some pretty cool stuff with lettering and screenprinting so I decided to make the treck down and show her how to airbrush and have her show me some screenprinting, which is surprising I haven't really gotten into before. I think I like the more hands-on methods of creating more.

This shirt features a "Living like I'm on vacation" screenprint made by T the night before. So I started with that as a baseline and decided to do vacation-inspired things to fill out the shirt. The obvious addition is the palm tree, but less obvious is the happy-neutral-mad faces that I swear to god I had seen on food packaging labels when I was in South America. The faces would indicate how healthy the snack was across various areas. I spent so long researching this trying to find what I know I saw but I could never find anything. Anyways, vacations always bring a lot of mixed feelings for me. They are super happy but at the same time neutral and at the same time usually make me kind of depressed.
Ayo Mista White! I don't really know what I got up to this day but yeah I painted the iconic image of Walter White from episode one of Breaking Bad onto this shirt.

This is another shirt that comes from an image that I had drawn while daydreaming in class. The skeleton is melting the ant hill with a magnifying glass, but on the back it says "just kidding! I would never do this! I love all of God's creations!". So yeah I guess this is a silly one.
Sticking with my star-eyed skeleton, I present ball is afterlife. Because ball is forever and I love basketball. Basketball is so much fun.

OOooooooh I really like this one a lot and would not mind holding onto it for myself in the long term. I just love the way it looks and there's not too much else to say about it. That night, A, S and I stayed in and watched a movie and probably had a few drinks.

This one reminds me of a field of strawberries. Like that Beatles song or whatever. Anyways I like it quite a lot and on the back there is a big skeleton head. I used so much green paint on this shirt. I had also been working on this stencil, spending hours and hours every day painstakingly cutting little dots out of plastic poster board.

I'm not really sure what inspired this one but on the front it says, "Ahahahahahahaha Nice." I guess I was feeling silly. I just took the picture of the back of this one though because I like the way that looks better. I do like the creme coloring though.

I finally finished cutting my stencil. I had spent probably over 20 hours over the course of the last week and a half cutting each of these tiny dots to reveal a halftone image of Mary holding Jesus, inspired by a piece I had seen in Prague. It just doesn't read as well as I wanted it to but oh well there's always the next shirt.

I made this shirt in a rush right before my class. Inspired by bubbles and my star-eyed skeleton motif. That star-eyed skeleton was a reflection of how I felt about myself at the time. Kind of dead inside but also so starry-eyed and full of silliness and wonder for the world. That little guy helped me be me.

The MSCHF big red boots had just dropped and been all over the internet. They received a lot of hate. A lot of people thought they were lame and too overhyped. Which is true, but at the same time I thought they were cool in how silly they were and how they pulled from video games and nostalgia. So I found a reference image of Astro Boy and switched his eyes out for the motif I was using at the time, the starry eyes.

I really liked how the previous day's shirt looked with Astro Boy and the black white and red colorway so I just made another one. I found it a lot more satisfying at times to just make things that I thought looked cool rather than force myself to come up with my own original drawings. After all, I was still the only one putting this on a shirt. That night I made a cartoon about Berlin for the first ever issue of Phase Zero, the coolest and hottest magazine in NYC made by my friends S and M.

This shirt is iconic. Maybe my favorite that I ever made. That might be an exaggeration, but it definitely unlocked a new gear of what I was creating, of what I imagined the shirts to be. I just thought this was funny and looked cool. From this point on, I began working far more heavily in Photoshop when planning the shirts rather than in my sketchbook. That night, we went out to the local bar Happyfun Hideaway.

When I started this whole project, I intended for it to create art every single day. The purpose was not silly shirts. But the real question is whether or not silly things like this can be considered as art. Is scooby doo pointing a gun at you art? I still think so. Maybe it holds me back from ever displaying my work in a museum or whatever. Is that trade off worth it? All these ideas would be bouncing around in my head and I would be pulling myself in all different sorts of directions throughout the project. But maybe its not even that deep, and I'm just putting too much weight on to all of this. Anyways yeah scooby doo holding a gun.

This shirt was made special for the Super Bowl. No relation to the band. I think it was the Eagles versus Kansas City. Not really sure, but that night I got some Budweiser and other drinks and got excessively crossed at B's place.

This is a failed attempt at trying to replicate the success of the Garfield with the crosses shirt. I just really liked the look of the two crosses marking either shoulder and was looking for something good to put with that but nothing could compare with that smug look on Garfield's face.

Valentines day shirt, made with the long lasting motif of the star eyed skeleton. I didn't have any sort of Valentines day date this year but that was okay. I had my shirts lol. I went to class and worked on photoshopping cartoon characters with religious symbols or with some wild captions.

Where shirt number 275 felt like a failed attempt to recreate the Garfield shirt, this shirt feels like a massive success. I really enjoyed being so blasphemous and just fucking with people in the crucified spongebob shirt. Feeling so unserious. I spent the previous day in class not paying attention at all and photoshopping this together.

This one is subconsciously Jesse Pinkman-inspired and one of my least favorites at the time but now is a shirt that I look back upon fondly. That night I went to hang out with my good friend G and he liked the shirt a lot.

Ooooh ooh oooh how I loved this shirt when I made it. The type of shirt I wanted to wear again the next day and probably again in another week when I was feeling upset again. The shirts would dictate a lot of my feelings in life, and being upset about the previous day's shirt, I was frustrated with my own emotions getting so overwhelming all the time. But anyways I felt super swag and had fun that night at Birdie's with friends.

I really wasn't sure what to make this night but for a while I had the idea of a stencil blastover shirt brewing in the back of my mind. I had all these random stencils that were just sitting there, waiting to be used again, so I just tried to focus on creating a cool composition with this shirt.

I really ended up loving the previous day's stencil blastover shirt, and given that I already had like four different rat stencils to work with, I decided to spend my day carving a whole bunch more of those rat stencils to make this shirt. I probably went a little overboard with it, piling way too many things on top of each other but at the end of the day I don't think that did any harm.

This shirt was pretty random, I just wanted to go for some sort of y2k aesthetic but work in those mickey mouse stencils from the previous day. A random spilling out of ideas is pretty fun. Felt like a baddie in this one.

I was running out of ideas but still stuck thinking about what I could do with cartoon characters. At the time, I was spending a whole bunch more time than I would've liked consuming TikToks rather than creating them. And the majority of those that I would watch were the family guy TikToks set to subway surfers or random mobile games. I thought it would be funny to have my airbrushing in place of those games. Surprisingly, I wasn't able to find any images of Peter Griffin bleeding from his eyes so I took it into my own hands to decide what that would look like.

Pulling from video games and cartoons was fun for me, and I have a special affinity for Duck Hunt as I would often run it as my Super Smash character and have fun blowing people up. Just as I was finishing this shirt I absentmindedly sprayed some purple onto the middle of the shirt, but I think that gives it a nice kind of easter egg. I also wanted to add the blue of the sky but didn't want to use a whole bunch of paint on the sky so I came up with my airbrush tie-dye look. Not sure if anyone else has done this effect with the airbrush but I am happy to claim that I started it (I think).

Another Duck Hunt shirt, kind of creating a storytelling effect between the two. Again, I just like Duck Hunt from the nostalgic feeling. Maybe I should have taken more artistic liberties with it, but I was mainly focused on just doing the best I could do with the airbrush, which I think I did a pretty nice job.

I made this one at night right before having a bunch of people over. I was planning on wearing it out and showing it off to people at the bar but we just ended up staying in and hosting a small function. This one is inspired by the airbrusher wreck pack, who is honestly the most talented airbrusher I have seen on the internet. I tried to replicate some things he has done with text with my own "some kid" words. This day I was really just feeling like some kid. Just one of many. It's a reassuring feeling, in a way.

I was really running thin on ideas, and luckily my roommate had recently bought a tapestry with this imagery on it so I decided to replicate it on the shirt. It also matched my jacket really well, not that it would really matter to whoever buys this because I am keeping my cool jacket for me.

And I feel just like a roach on its back. This one is inspired by the song A_X by Dean Blunt, who inspired a whole bunch of shirts over the course of the year. His music is so beautiful and amazing but then I get embarrassed talking about my love for him because one time I saw a meme about white guys loving Dean Blunt and now I don't want to fit into that meme but I can't help it. Earlier in the year I found a roach in my room and now the roach sits on his back under a wine glass that I have yet to remove.

Joe camel playing piano. I'm not sure where, but I saw something about old cigarette advertisements and how they were directed at children, and I was like wow holy shirt Joe Camel is so cool and I want to smoke cigarettes. So I looked up some old Joe Camel ads and chose to make this one into a shirt because it looked the coolest. The next day, my professor told me that she really liked my shirt and I didn't even tell her that I made it.

The start of "Prague Week", where I spent an entire week making shirts based on photos that I had taken while being in Prague a month earlier. Each of the shirts of this week took an average of three hours to complete. I was extremely focused on creating things that are beautiful and photo-realistic. These shirts were so cool to me and I was so proud that I made them. The shading is just so phenomenal and spot-on. This night, I went to the release of the first issue of Phase Zero, the super cool magazine reporting on the underground NYC scene that my friends S and M created.

The second of the Prague Week shirts, and probably the most detailed shirt I have ever made. I'm so proud of this. It depicts the burning of Jan Hus, a pivotal point in Czech history. The only downside to making these shirts was that they would take so long that I wouldn't have any time to wear them outside before I went to sleep and had to wake up and make a new one.

Serving victory. Success. Love. The third Prague Week shirt, made based on another statue that I saw when visiting Vysehrad in Prague. There's not even too much to say about these shirts, other than the fact that I wanted to create something beautiful. Something that stands out in my mind though, is that you might see this on a shirt with text or something like that to give it context. But I think I like it better without the context. The shirt speaks for itself.

This shirt is inspired by another print depicting the burning of Jan Hus that I took a photo of while in Prague. This one features far less detail than the one from a few days prior, but still very cool in my opinion.

This depicts an image that was a part of a burial or headstone or something and had been relocated to the Czech National Museum. I wanted to create Prague-inspired shirts for an entire week and this one is the weakest of them all but still is special to me as it was a part of that week.

I think I went a little too dark and harsh on the lines on this one, compared to the others in Prague Week that are more photo-realistic with focus on shading. This one is more graphic, but there's nothing really wrong with that. This image is of a statue of an angel that sat atop a giant tomb I saw in Vysehrad in Prague.

This is the finale of the Prague Week shirts, and definitely one of the best. It features a statue of Jan Å½iÅ¾ka, a famous Prauge war general who had one eye and was super badass and led armies that defeated the Crusaders. He was on some real this is Sparta, 300-type shit, leading a small yet strong army against a much larger one and coming out victorious, despite eventually being defeated. I don't think the photo does this one justice. I went crazy with the shading on the horse. Seeing this statue in person is crazy, its so incredibly huge. For reference, a human is probably about as tall as half of one of those blocks at the bottom of the statue. This night was A's birthday, and we spent a few hours putting up decorations to throw him a nice surprise party.

After riding on that Prague week high for seven days, I was bound to fall back to earth and make something that I didn't like nearly as much. But you know, that's okay. I'm sure someone will recognize that this shirt is still pretty cool, even if I didn't think so. I had just set a certain standard for myself where I would feel bad if I wasn't making something even cooler and more impressive than what I had made the day before. On the back, there's another skeleton with some hearts.

I can't lie, I kind of stole this idea from my roommate A who had borrowed my airbrush the previous night to make this design with the cardboard netting on a shirt. I kind of distorted it in a way that was different than he did though, and I didn't feel so bad because he had kept me up until like 3AM the night before working on his shirt. It's cool thinking about how everything can be a stencil though. Our good friend B came into town this day and we hung out and made rapchats.

Still on the "everything and anything can be a stencil" wave, I made this shirt with the dozens of empty cans of Celcius I had sitting around. I would drink them every day, sometimes two a day, completely addicted to energy drinks in order to stay awake in the slightest. This was the start of my Spring Break, and my mom got into town that night so I met her out for dinner.

I was planning on making a Chief Keef shirt for day 300 but completely missed the fact that this was day 300. So I went a little bit meta and used the hangers I put my shirts on as a stencil for a design that would be on this shirt. The design looks cool though, like some sort of spine or skeleton under an x-ray. I went to the Thierry Mugler exhibit at the Brooklyn Museum with my mom and had a nice day. That night, my mom took my friends and I out for dinner.

This one is inspired by an ad I had seen at the Thierry Mugler exhibit the day before. I wish I put more effort into this one, but for some reason I didn't really care because I just wanted to spend five minutes on it and drink some beer. But anyways I think its so cool that Mugler would direct his own ad shoots and do them in crazy ass places. He would have these models in the most precarious situations and I just wonder how he convinced them to do that. It seems crazy to me. But so cool.

I saw some sort of drawing of a girl on instagram this day and took my own artistic liberties to turn it into this. I never really draw on anime or anything like that for inspiration but that's what this ended up looking like, and it turned out pretty well in my opinion.

It was pretty stupid of me to pour wine on this shirt, but that's what I did. This night we were having some fine dining with some home-cooked pasta and red wine. I was tired of all of my things looking too similar so I think that's why I poured the wine on it. Idk.

Still thinking back to my Prague week, I was looking for something to pull a bunch of inspiration from. So this week, I looked back at some collages I had made in the months before starting the shirt project. This one features the face of a guy with all the holes cut out and a red background. This day marked exactly two months left until the completion of the project, which just felt so crazy to me. So much weight.
I love this shirt so much lol. It is based on a collage I made of Princess Diana's arm holding a Yerba Mate bottle, which really just speaks for itself.

This shirt is based on a collage I made with a bunch of guys sticking their heads up each other's butts in a human centipede. Idk like do I have to spell it out. I didn't color or shade this one because I think the design speaks for itself. Detailing it might muddy it up. This night, I went out with my roommates and we had a whole bunch of fun dancing in Manhattan. It's fun going out in surprising shirts like this one and seeing people's reactions. It's like a real time social commentary or something idk it just feels cool.

This was one of my favorites of the old collages I had translated into shirts. Blowing up tiny images and getting all those details in there feels really cool. I should probably return to collaging for the stuff I make in the future, because it makes it so much easier to create compositions. I am bad at drawing, so it feels good to create something original without having to draw. This night, I went out with A to meet up with H and our old roommate A. We had fun at the Queens Brewery and played pool and I got a really high score on the punching bag arcade game.

This is based on another collage I had made where I cut out faces from this book of New Mexican religious imagery and art and pasted it onto a guide showing the phases of the moon. This one is all crooked and off a little but still really cool and perfect for everybody into astrology as a bit of a commentary on that. This day, I went up to Harlem to shoot an interview of Branson, a well-respected cannabis legacy grower who used to sell weed to Biggie. It was really cool he gave me a free bag of his own weed.

This is a small snapshot of a collage I had made with S when she visited me a year earlier. The faces come from these drug abuse prevention pamphlets that I had found scattered all over the street. This collage was really a breakthrough for me in creating collage repetitions, mainly through how cool repeating images over top of one another could look. Later on, I would print multiple copies of whatever I wanted to collage with to achieve this effect. This was also one of my favorite shirts I had ever made because it is not immediately readable but then has a lot of detail and interesting features when you really look.

This is the final of the weeks worth of shirts that I made in reference to my old collages. This one, unlike the other shirts, does not really do the original collage justice. I think the original image is of Moses atop a mountain. Scanned in high resolution, the image just looks and feels so holy and ethereal. That night I had really deep and existential conversation with S and S.

This shirt is inspired by my favorite song at the time, In The Life Zone by Dwight Sykes. For some reason that song never really fails to get me into a good mood when I'm feeling sad, even though the lyrics are kind of the opposite. My class that morning was cancelled but I was in the city anyways, so I had a great time killing three hours and just wandering aimlessly around Manhattan.

I had to make this one in a rush before meeting up with S at a pub in midtown for some drinks, but something compelled me to take the extra time to tape off all the borders. This shirt would lead to another evolution in my style, as after this point I would spend a lot of time taping off all my designs to give them a cool rendered sort of look to them. The airbrush is such a strong and versatile tool in this way. I really liked this one, even though it's trash. After hanging out with S for a bit I met up with my friends T and O, who was visiting, and we went to a few bars in the East Village.

This shirt is based on a painting I saw at some random millennial lady's apartment after leaving H's one night the week before. I really wanted to buy that painting off her but it was the one thing in her apartment sale that she was not willing to part with. Anyways, the memory of that painting lives on through this shirt. This day, I also painted my converses black with the airbrush and that worked out surprisingly well.

I ran out of time to make something on this one because I spent the morning and most of my day shooting photos for a cannabis event thing that I was recruited for. It was nice and worth my time going to that shoot even though it was pouring rain. I saw the Ocky Way deli on my way there. That night, for some reason, we were going to the New School prom so I made this shirt in honor of all the New School students who love to smoke cigs. The meme I took it from also had an image of Drake naked that really would have improved this piece but I just didn't have the time. The prom sucked but I'm glad I went because it was really comical how bad it sucked.

This image comes from the cover of a book I had seen at the Brooklyn Museum a few weeks earlier, called Submission by Jimmy De Sana. At this point in time with the shirts, I just felt like I was in a mad dash towards the finish and was willing to pull from anything and everything for inspiration. That's really the point of the whole project and where I come from as an artist, really seeing inspiration in everything and not being afraid to steal like an artist.

Pulling from memes and pop culture is one of my favorite things to do when working on clothes, and I really think I nailed this portrait of my beautiful king LeBron James. As an artist and airbrusher, I feel like what I decide to create says the most about anything, more than the quality or artistic value of the painting or anything like that. I'm proud of my ideas.

This is another shirt that pulls imagery from collages I had made in the past. I'm not sure exactly where the A's come from, but I just remember thinking oh it would be cool if I were to just cut out all these A's. Letters and typography are such a cool thing.

I think I did a great job on this shirt. It took forever to tape everything off but it was definitely worth it. I just regret that I had to pull this image of a chair from the internet. It makes me more inclined to take pictures of everything I see that might be even the slightest bit interesting. Everything is interesting. Everything is important. I also worked on a commission for Honeysuckle magazine this day, and that airbrushing eventually ended up in a print magazine which was cool.

This was one of my favorite shirts I have ever made, and inspired me to try to continue to blow up really tiny things to a high scale in future shirts. For over a month at this point, I had a pop tab safety pinned to my jeans that I would wear every day. That little safety pin and pop tab felt special to me. They were for style, but more for some sort of spiritual protection. I had become infatuated with totems of all sorts over the past year, beginning with rocks and gems that gave you some sort of astrological powers or whatever until I got tired of those and they left my life when I needed them to. Then, new totems came into my life at different points and served as reminders of who I am. They grounded me. I'm not even sure if totems are the right word but either way its important to me to have little trinkets or things that I can look at to center myself. This night, my cousin T was in town and he took me to an Icona Pop release show which was fun.

Really loving the concept of the previous day's shirt, I was looking for small and shiny things to blow up to look really big and cool on a shirt. My roommate S let me take a photo of his favorite ring, which is the basis for this shirt.

I liked the idea of the safety pins, despite the fact that taping them off added about 90 minutes onto the time it took me to create my shirts. On this one, I purposefully taped with more jagged edges in certain places to put more of my own artistic spin on things. This night, I went over to N's place to take part in her senior thesis project where I rolled a dice to receive a random tattoo. I ended up getting the paper fortune teller one, which I was really happy about because I used to make those things all the time when I was in grade school. Later, we went to a really fun house party and I don't have too much to say about it other than the fact that I wish there were way more house parties like that in New York because it was a great time.

I was feeling really stuck this day and my projector and my airbrush were both malfunctioning so I just ended up making this shitty ass talking tom shirt. I was inspired by learning about how Talking Tom was actually used to spy on kids and so this shirt depicts him getting locked up for that.

This one pulls inspiration from just being a child of the internet, and the age we live in. I don't really know how to express my thinking on this one, but I just know I like it. This day, I booked the space that I would use for my show to display all 365 of my shirts. For a while, it had been weighing on me that I was unsure of where I would hold this show. I was so unsure, and had no faith that the 365 show would be able to live up to what I envisioned in my head. Or even that what I envisioned the show being would be nothing in comparison to what the past year had been for me.

This shirt holds a special place in my heart. I think it was because of the fact that I learned a few weeks later that my childhood dog, Carmen, was terminally sick with a huge tumor in her stomach. She died about two weeks after the completion of the 365 project. Carmen is a golden-colored pitbull, depicted in the upper center of this shirt. RIP Carmen. She was a great dog.

This is another shirt following the theme of blowing up tiny small things to be all big and huge and cool-looking on a shirt. At the end of the day though, I don't think this one is as cool as I envisioned it in my head. Kind of gives Subway wall art.

I felt so swagged out this day. For some reason I was just really happy in general. I think maybe I had landed a date or something. Either way, I had just found out about this lil dude Pete the Cat and was honored to put his cool ass on my shirt. I also made myself a personal piece that I would be able to wear whenever I wanted, because I was tired of not being able to wear the things I liked again after making them, and I had such a big pool of things that I had already made and loved to pull from.

Not really sure where exactly the inspiration on this comes from, other than the fact that it's really nice to paint shiny metallic things with an airbrush. I had an extra button up too so I made this design twice, with an extra one on the button-up. That night, we went out in Park Slope and I was kind of sad but I had a really good time wandering around with A. We got McDonalds and rode on a carnival horse.

This one is for all the airbrushers out there. I hope you appreciate it. Just like the other days of putting shiny things on my shirts, I did this one with the airbrush that is on the shirt itself. On the back it says "congratulations on your genuine iwata", just like it says on the box.

This shirt was made on Easter, and I wanted to do something to represent those sweet springtime vibes without doing something directly religious, which I had really strayed away from at this point in the year. The reference image comes from a collage of flowers and leaves I had collected around the city two summers prior.

The day before, I had taken a bunch of photos of people on the subway for inspiration, including this one of some kids playing around. I wanted to work on some sort of collection revolving around the people of New York and turning everyday things into something interesting or beautiful, but I think the uncomfortability of taking photos of strangers has kept me from doing that. This day, I went to the second annual Making It group show, where I met up with a bunch of the artists who I had met back on day 41 of the project. I love all of the artists in that collective. They are an amazing and loving group of people that gave me so much motivation for the project over the course of the year.

This image of the carnival horse comes from a photo A had taken of me a few days earlier. I made this one in the middle of an online class that I cared so incredibly little about, and it ended up being one of the shirts I like quite a lot.

About a year earlier, my dad had come to visit and took A and I out to dinner at a nice Venezuelan place. After dinner, we went to a thrift shop where they had books filled with archive fashion, where I took this picture of a girl jumping in what looks to be some sort of leather fireman's coat or something. I messed up her face a little bit but I got the leather real nice. This night, I went to the release of the second issue of Phase Zero, which is the only issue I have not contributed to, but they did put a photo of me in there.

This was the day I got my favorite tattoo I've ever gotten. I snuck out of class to go print the image of my tattoo before going out to Crown Heights after class to visit F at his AirBnB where I got tattooed. F is someone who has been a major supporter of mine throughout the project, and it was an honor to get tattooed by him. I really look up to him, and it was so cool getting tatted because I was actually able to become friends with him and yeah it was just such an amazing feeling. He was one of the people that really inspired me to get an airbrush machine, and I can't thank him enough for that. Later in the day, I found this statue in the Parsons building and decided to put that on my shirt for the day, but to do something interesting with the composition by making two of them.

I saw some image of Kirby online, which inspired this shirt, but I didn't want to put just the Kirby on the shirt so I took a while thinking of how I would make it my own. Then I thought of the Kirb Your Enthusiasm, which is just gold in my opinion. I do have a little bit of regret not putting Larry David glasses and hair on kirby but it still ended up being a banger. This day I linked up with S, B, and G in Washington Square Park and had what felt like the first day of the summer.

I kind of butchered this one, but it is in reference to a red dollar bill I saw on Virgil Abloh's website that I then turned into a slightly crumpled $100. If I were to make this one today I would probably do more to distort the bill and maybe add more colors or something. That day, I thought of the idea that would be my poster for the show and I recruited A to come with me to B's roof to help shoot it. I layed out over 200 of the shirts to spell out the text for the poster. And this was it, I had one month to go until the project was officially completed.

This shirt was made in a rush while my friends were waiting for me before going out. It was funny, throughout the year, my friends asking what I was up to and me responding that I was going to make a shirt. It was probably annoying at times, waiting for me to make a shirt or just the fact that they were so prevalent on my mind that shirts were one of the only things I would talk about. It was hard having that sort of one track-mind, but it was necessary. At the time, I was grabbing the wet paint signs from the subway every time I saw one, and that's what inspired this shirt.

This concludes a little tryptic of red rectangles, with a reference to Courtney Barnett's song "Anonomous Club", where she says, "let's start an anonymous club/ we'll wear name badges with question marks".

Of course I love my pop culture references, but this one was special to me in how it relates to my project as a whole. Every day, I would wake up and go "ah shit, here we go again", and I would make another shirt. This was also the day I found out my childhood dog, Carmen, was terminally sick, and I cried a little bit, but I didn't want to dwell on it so I went out to my friend M!les Ave's show and listened to some beautiful music and saw some beautiful people.

Again referencing the project as a whole and this time the previous day's shirt as well, I made a second version of the "ah shit, here we go again" shirt, this time with the background of the image because I felt like the first one was lacking a little bit and was not as recognizeable without the background. The airbrush is especially nice on this one, and on making anything in a video game-graphic style.
