Continuing with the idea of video game graphics, I made this SNES controller with the graphics of how it would look if it were actually rendered in that sort of style. It's nice working this way because taping things off becomes a lot easier when you can do it more blocky and don't have to conform to curves. That day, I helped out with a video shoot in Times Square. And that night, we went out to a weird apartment party where the apartment had almost nothing in it and was just super grimy and sketchy feeling. I'm glad I went though.

This shirt was made a day late for 4/20, and was the basis for a video interview that was never published but was intended to be displayed on this shirt, where the shirt would be a green screen and the video of the interview would play on the shirt. Maybe if all this gets enough attention I'll publish that video one day.

I made a blocky-style globe in honor of earth day. While I was out going for a walk, I saw a massive fire which was kind of sad because it was earth day but the firefighters did a good job and put the fire out and no one was hurt so at least there's that.

If you happen to be reading the captions on all of these shirts, which I'm sure pretty much no one is doing, but if you were to be you would see that a lot of them are inspired by music. I thought about putting a specific song beneath the cat that it would be listening to but its too hard to choose. I feel like I could make like 20 of these shirts, all with different songs, and it would be a cool little series.

This shirt is based off an image of my little sister that I tried to abstract and create more of a graphic look to it, but I think I should have done even more taping for the shading to achieve the look that I envisioned. Either way, little kid outfits go crazy. The turtleneck and jean dress with the flower embroidery is something I feel like I would definitely see somebody wearing today.

As is custom, whenever I made a shirt honoring one of my little sisters, I must make another honoring the other. This is based off a photo taken back at my old childhood home probably around 2008 or something, and features my old dog Sparky's paws above my little sister who was layed out on the kitchen floor. This is definitely the best photo-realistic portrait I have done, and I credit it to not over-shading. Way too often I would be doing too much and painting just to paint, rather than being more intentional with my placement of shadows.

The previous day, I had woken up bright and early to go up to the Bronx and be a part of a photoshoot at the stairs from the Joker movie, which was a really cool experience despite the fact that I was super under-rested. So for this shirt, I painted a photo that I had taken through the lens of the vhs camera I was using to shoot with. This one is so chaotic but I love it, especially with the text from the vhs being over-top of the image.

I think I just saw an image on instagram of some polar bears who had taken over some buildings in this abandoned Russian town, and they look so cute and cool. Polar bears are my favorite animal, I think.

This image is of me back in 2005, when I insisted on wearing the Wiggles outfit to preschool every day. My mom made me a custom Wiggles pin and belt, and got me all four color turtlenecks, which I would wear on a rotating schedule along with my black slacks and dress shoes. For Halloween I was Captain Feathersword. This might be my favorite photo of all time, with my little sister crawling by in front of me as I blare some sort of terrible song out of my recorder. This night, I went to a comedy show where my roommate S had a set, but I was late and missed it unfortunately.

A few days earlier, we had gone over to A's parent's place in Bed Stuy where I saw these lions guarding the entrance to a brownstone. I didn't really like how this shirt turned out though, but I'm not sure why. That night, we went out in the West Village for E's birthday and I ended up going home a little early because I was sleepy.

Again referencing internet and meme culture, this was a favorite of mine. It was the perfect shirt for this day, as there were terribly strong thunderstorms happening all day and the image on the shirt was really the vibe of being outside that day. I went to S's apartment in midtown that day and worked for hours with my capstone group finalizing our final presentation.

I was hitting the home stretch with my shirts, just two weeks to go, and really feeling like some sort of prodigy with this project. It was really hitting me how crazy I was to do this whole thing and really hitting me how I had done it and yeah I wanted to make a silly little shirt to represent that. Again referencing the internet culture, as well as the motivational posters that would hang up in schools back in the early 2000s, I made this shirt that I really liked. This day I went to S's midtown apartment to finish up our group project, and then met up with friends from my old journalism class to go get food in Chinatown.

A few days prior, as I waited for the subway, I watched as a woman washed the graffiti off of a wall. Processes of the removal of art are really interesting to me, along with the cyclical nature of restoration and decay. It kind of falls in line with the "wet paint" shirt. Also the aspect of storytelling is fun to get into whenever I have the chance.

It was finals week in my last semester of school and I was swamped all day so I ended up just making this one really quick in like 20 minutes at the end of the day. I still really like it though. That fish dude looks super chill and I feel like a super chill guy wearing it. I also made four shirts for my group's project that we wore for our final presentation, even though I felt super corny doing that but it was cool.

I know I say it a lot but this is probably some of the best work I have ever done, and one of my favorite pieces I have ever made. First, in the morning, my group gave our final presentation for our senior capstone project. The presentation went incredibly well, and I was finally done with school. A few days earlier, when I was meeting at S's midtown apartment to finalize the presentation, I came across a long line of busses waiting to pick up kids from school and snapped photos of all of them. Later, I photoshopped all the busses together and spent a solid three hours painting this shirt. My friend called it a "biblically accurate angel" which I think is very fitting. That night, I went out drinking with S and E from my group project. We hopped around to a few different bars, finally getting the chance to spend time together outside of the context of school, and made our way to the Hudson river shore as the night turned to day. I watched the sunrise through the window of the M train moving across the Williamsburg Bridge.

I spent most of this day recovering from the previous night before going on a date near the end of the day. My date helped me out with the idea for this shirt because I showed her my idea of basketball Mario but wasn't sure what player to tie it to and her Manu suggestion was perfect. I got home from that pretty late and just made the shirt and fell asleep so I could get up early the next day to go shoot this cannabis parade so I could write a story about it for my journalism class.

This was a crazy long day, started off by leaving the house still underrested to go shoot this NYC cannabis parade so I could submit something and not fail my journalism class. After shooting and getting a good amount of interviews at the parade, I met up with my friends for a day at Prospect Park. I had gotten a free shirt at the cannabis parade and wore it to not stain my white shirt on the grass. It was my first time wearing a non-white t-shirt all year. We brought beers and shrooms and had such a fun day in the sun, running around and playing, and eventually all taking our shoes off and walking eight miles around the park as the sun started to come down from the sky and we found ourselves skipping stones by the lake. Then, we walked to Z's apartment as the sun set and went out for tacos near her place before making our way home late at night. I was exhausted and had zero ideas for what to make, but made this shirt with A and A from earlier in the day as they both slept in the room next to me.

I went on a morning walk to secure my daily caffeine intake and saw this beautiful classic car that I snapped some photos of. I painted two of them to make the composition more interesting, and it reminded me of that I Think You Should Leave skit with Bob Odenkirk and the classic cars. Later in the day I went on another date. We smoked weed and I showed her how to airbrush but we weren't really feeling each other and that was the last time I saw her.

Down the block from me there was this busted up Honda Oddessy that was always parked in the same spot, and I liked painting the cars on the previous day's shirt. Every shirt builds upon the previous one, with how I see it. It was a wild feeling being in these final ten days of the project. Rather than the stress involved with making a shirt day after day, each day was marked with a twinge of melancholy without any of the anxiety. There was a sense of catharsis as well. Calm.

Again contrasting with the previous day's shirt, I painted a kiddie Benz that I saw while walking down the street a few days earlier. This day marked one week left of the project. It was a strange feeling. I no longer felt any sort of overwhelming high or low from making a shirt that I liked, or just making a shirt that I knew I could make. At this point the shirts were more of an afterthought to my upcoming show to display all of them. It was still so freeing to make the shirts though. I was doing what I loved.

This was a fun one to make, and one that I'm really glad exists in the world. Towards the end of the project I took focus on what lies at the root of my work as a whole, which is finding artistic inspiration in everything and anything around you, especially the mundane. Certain things that we see every day become complete afterthoughts, yet hold intrinsic value that is not uncovered until we as artists reveal it. I walk by that BP pretty much every day and never thought twice about it beyond the fact that it's rare to see gas stations in New York. I thought about adding more imagery from the gas station, but I think it's pretty cool with just the sign, looking almost like a humanoid figure.

This was such a long day. I had the final class of my college career with my final project group and we continued to hang out until 4 after our 9AM class. We were waiting on the news on whether or not our group would be selected to be on the panel of the BBA Symposium, which was a really big deal to us. Eventually we split, still nervous about the decision. I wandered through Manhattan for a bit, got a decent vegan burger, and snapped a bunch of photos of stop lights before hopping on the subway. I got the call from S and E while walking home and was ecstatic, we did it. I thought about collaging the stoplight photos together but then just went with the one.

This was the fourth from final shirt, and my friend J was in town visiting. For this shirt I found an old photo I took of a bulldozer and stretched it out to be nice and tall. I look back on some of these shirts and think it would have been cool if I added more color, but at the time I was focused on just getting the shirt done with for the day because I had other stuff to do. I met T and J at Tompkins and then ran into my friends E and S there before going out drinking w T and J. I got super tired that night and fell asleep waiting for the subway. I must have had some sort of luck on my side that kept my phone that was sitting on my lap from getting stolen.

With the third-to-last shirt, I made something that I'm pretty proud of. I had the idea of putting my own face on the shirt for a while, all the way back to the start of the project, and decided it was finally the time to do it. Back to my roots in a way, I was just trying to do something that no one had really seen before and be funny. That night, we went out to I's birthday party and it was nice getting a bunch of reactions out of people.

This was Mother's Day and the second-to-last day of the project. I spent the day looking through old photos and calling my mom and family. I kind of messed up the portrait but its of me and my mom laying in the grass. That night I went over to H's and had a good time hanging out up on the roof with her and G and A. G and A bet me to do a cannonball into the kiddie pool roof up there so I stripped down to my underwear and made a quick $60. I went to bed anxious that night, thinking about the fact that I would wake up the next day and make the last shirt.

I decided it would be best to keep things simple with this final shirt. I hung the blank shirt up and spent about half an hour just looking at it. It was a surreal feeling. It only took me five minutes to make this one. I got chills as I put it on. There was a strange sense of bliss. As I rode the subway over to the city I spent extra time looking up at the city and the people around me. Energy buzzed through my body. But I had to turn my focus towards the BBA Symposium happening that night. The symposium was a graduation celebration and final showcase of everyone's work, a true conclusion. I had no idea the days would line up like this when I started the project. That night, my group was one of the few to have our project displayed to hundreds more people and have the opportunity to speak as a part of a panel. Then I thanked my professors, had a few glasses of wine, and went out with E and her friends. I sat in the 1st Ave L station for half an hour waiting for my train home. I had done it. The project was over. Two days later, I officially graduated and held my show where I displayed all 365 of the shirts.
